questions.text: The Image given below shows Kiesselbach's plexus formed in the Little's area of nasal septum. Which of the following artery does not participates in formation of Kiesselbach's plexus?
questions.solution:
The Kiesselbach plexus, also known as Little’s area, is a vascular region in the nasal septum that’s made up of five arteries:

Sphenopalatine artery: A branch of the maxillary artery, which originates behind the jawbone

Anterior ethmoidal artery: A branch of the ophthalmic artery, which originates behind the eye

Septal branch of the superior labial artery: A branch of the facial artery

Greater palatine artery: A terminal branch of the maxillary artery

The Kiesselbach plexus receives blood from the internal and external carotid arteries. The blood drains from the area through the ophthalmic veins, facial vein, and pterygoid plexus.

Prominent blood vessels in the Kiesselbach plexus can cause nosebleeds, also known as epistaxis.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. His endoscopy examination image is given below. It is suggestive of primary atrophic rhinitis. Which of the following is not a feature of primary atrophic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Atrophic rhinitis is a condition that occurs when the tissue inside the nose becomes thin and causes irritation. Symptoms include:

Nasal obstruction: The nasal passages may feel blocked, even though they are roomy.

Crusting: A foul-smelling crust may form inside the nose.

Nosebleeds: Chronic nosebleeds may occur, especially when removing the crust.

Loss of smell: The nerve endings that sense smell may become atrophied, making it difficult to smell.

Nasal deformity: The nose may develop a saddle-nose deformity.

Sinus infections: Sinus infections may occur.

Bad breath: Halitosis may occur.

Dryness: The nasal passages may feel dry.

Atrophic rhinitis can be caused by a number of factors, including:

Bacterial infections, Vitamin deficiencies, Structural issues at birth, Family history, Injury, Allergies, Estrogen imbalances, and Autoimmune disease.

Treatments for atrophic rhinitis can include: saline sprays, nasal irrigation, nutritional supplements, and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presented with a compressible swelling over the posterior triangle of neck as shown in the figure. It is noted to have bright translucency. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cystic hygroma is a form of lymphatic malformation. Also known as cystic lymphangioma and macrocystic lymphatic malformation, the growth is often a congenital lymphatic lesion of many small cavities (multiloculated) that can arise anywhere, but is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck and armpits.

Cystic hygromas are benign, but can be disfiguring. It is a condition which usually affects children. on examination, cystic hygromas are soft, fluctuate, and freely mobile, and they transilluminate well. They are typically non-pulsatile and increase in size with coughing and crying.

questions.text: Identify the lymphoid tissue shown in the following diagram.
questions.solution:
Microscopic structure of the spleen:

  • Capsule:
    • Covers the spleen completely.
    • Lies deep to the mesothelial covering (peritoneum).
    • It is formed by dense collagenous connective tissue and few smooth muscle fibres.
    • Contraction of these muscles cause pumping of blood from the spleen into the circulation.
    • Spleen acts as a reservoir of blood.
  • Trabeculae:
    • Trabeculae are given off from the capsule into the substance of spleen.
    • They are thick and robust.
    • Carry trabecular vessels which are branches of splenic vessels.
  • Reticular Stroma:
    • It is made of reticular fibres and associated phagocytic reticular cells, forming a meshwork throughout the organ.
    • Supports the cells of parenchyma.
  • Parenchyma:
    • The interior of spleen shows rounded white/grey areas surrounded by red matrix.
    • These round grey areas are called white pulp and the dark red matrix is called red pulp.
  • White Pulp:
    • Microscopically, white pulp is made of aggregation of lymphoid tissue around a small artery or arteriole.
    • This artery is a branch of trabecular artery that leaves the trabeculum and enters the pulp.
    • On entering the pulp it is surrounded by lymphoid tissue, the periarterial lymphatic sheath (PALS), populated by T lymphocytes, to become central artery or white pulp artery.
  • Red pulp:
    • Red pulp is a modifi ed lymphoid tissue, heavily infi ltrated with all the cells of the circulating blood, giving a dark red colour to the tissue in fresh state.
    • It is composed of irregular anastomosing splenic cords of Bilroth and broad splenic venous sinuses in between the cords.

Reference: Figure from Difiore's Atlas of Histology, 12th Edition

questions.text: Which section of the cause of death certificate is used to record conditions contributing to the death but not directly related to the underlying cause of death?
questions.solution:
Death Certificate (Certificate of cause of death)

The basis of mortality data is the Death Certificate. For ensuring national and international comparability, it is very necessary to have a uniform and standardized system of recording and classifying deaths. The death certificate recommended by WHO for international use is given in Figure.

In India, Death Certificate is a vital record signed by a licensed physician or another designated health worker, that includes cause of death, decedent’s name, sex, birth date, adhar number, place of residence and of death, and whether the deceased had been medically attended before death. Occupation, birth place, and other information may be included.

It will be seen from figure that the international certificate of cause of death is in two parts. Part I deals with the immediate cause of death and the underlying cause.

"Causes of death: The causes of death to be entered on the medical certificate of cause of death are all those diseases, morbid conditions, or injuries that either resulted in or contributed to death and circumstances of the accident or violence which produced any such injuries.

Underlying cause of death: The underlying cause of death is (1) the disease or injury that initiated the train of events leading to death or (2) the circumstances of the accident or violence that produced the fatal injury."

In Part II is recorded any significant associated disease that contributed to the death but did not directly lead to it.

questions.text: All of the following structure is forming the boundaries of the marked foramen in the figure, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Foramen Epiploicum (Foramen of Winslow):

  • The foramen epiploicum is a vertical slit through which lesser sac of peritoneum (omental bursa) communicates with the greater sac of peritoneum.
  • It is situated behind the right free margin of lesser omentum at the level of T12 vertebra.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior:
      • Right free border of the lesser omentum
      • Bile duct (Option A)
      • Vertical part of the hepatic artery (Option D)
      • Portal vein (Option B).
    • Posterior:
      • Inferior vena cava
      • Right suprarenal gland.
    • Superior:
      • Caudate process of the caudate lobe of the liver
    • Inferior:
      • First part of the duodenum
      • Horizontal part of the hepatic artery (Option D)
    • Hepatic vein (Option C): it does not form boundary of the epiploic foramen.

KEY NOTE - Pringle manoeuver - clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament (free border of lesser omentum) to differentiate if the bleeding is due to hepatic artery or portal vein

Tag: Abdomen (peritoneum)

questions.text: In this image following type of neuron is seen in
questions.solution:
• Unipolar: Having only one pole
    Present in embryonic stage (all developing neurons) in human being
    Eg. Mesencephalic nucleus of 5th cranial nerve
  • Bipolar: Having two poles
    Axon arises one pole and dendrites other pole
    Eg. In retina, vestibular ganglion, olfactory epithelium, cochlea
  • Pseudo unipolar: From single pole both axon and dendrites arise
    These types of neurons are first typically bipolar but they converge to meet on one side of cell body and elongates to form T shaped process
    Eg. In spinal ganglia and ganglia of all cranial nerves except 8th cranial nerve
  • Multipolar: Nucleus having multipoles
    Axon arise one pole & all other pole give rise dendrites
    Eg. Motor neurons in spinal cord, Pyramidal cells, Purkinje cells in cerebellum.

Tag: Neuronal classification

questions.text: Match the following:

• Option C - Enterokinase is an enzyme secreted from the cells of small intestine it causes activation of trypsinogen to trypsin. Trypsin is a protein digesting enzyme.

    1. Trypsinogen to trypsin

    3. Procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase
  • Option B - Aminopeptidase is an enzyme that causes breakdown of polypeptide into aminoacids.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pepsin begins the digestion of protein in the acidic medium of the stomach. Digestion continues with the pancreatic proteases (trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase and carboxypeptidases A and B which are the essential enzymes).

Protein digestion is completed by small intestinal brush border enzymes, dipeptidases, and an aminopeptidases. The main end product are amino acids (40%) and dipeptides and tripeptides(60%)

questions.text: What does the lotus symbolize in that programme?
questions.solution:
The emblem of the National Leprosy Education Programme symbolizes beauty and purity through the image of a lotus. It conveys the message that leprosy is a curable disease and that individuals affected by leprosy can lead productive lives in society. This idea is represented by a partially affected thumb and a normal forefinger, forming the shape of a house. The rising sun in the emblem symbolizes hope and optimism, capturing the spirit of positive action and the eradication of leprosy.

Clinical Features of Leprosy:

  • Hypopigmented patches on the skin
  • Partial or total loss of sensation in affected areas
  • Thickened nerves
  • Presence of acid-fast bacilli in skin or nasal smears

questions.text: Identify that following normal ECG is taken from lead
questions.solution:
LIMB LEADS

AUGMENTED LEADS

  • Depolarization moving toward an active electrode produces a positive deflection, whereas depolarization moving in the opposite direction produces a negative deflection.
  • Unipolar limb leads measure the potential differences between exploring electrode (attached positive terminal of the electrocardiograph) and indifferent electrode.
  • aVR is the potential difference between RA (positive electrode) & (LA + LL).
  • aVL is the potential difference between LA ((positive electrode) & (RA + LL).
  • Option B - In Lead I negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm and positive terminal to the left arm.
  • Option C - Lead V4 - exploring (positive terminal) electrode in midclavicular line in the fifth left intercostal space.
  • Option A - If we observe above leads in aVR the summed up current flows opposite to the exploring electrode producing negative deflection in QRS complex.
  • In the remaining leads the summedup current flows in the direction of exploring electrode producing positive QRS complex

KEY TAKE AWAYS: If the current flows towards active electrode-positive deflection

If the current flows away from the active electrode - negative deflection

Tag: ECG

choices.text: The first-generation IUDs contain copper, while the third generation contains hormones.
The second-generation IUDs are hormone-releasing devices, such as progestasert.
Non-medicated IUDs are referred to as first-generation, and copper IUDs are second-generation IUDs.
Hormone-releasing IUDs are classified as first-generation IUDs.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the different generations of Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)?
questions.solution:
• The image given is of IUD ( intra uterine device ). There are two basic types of IUDs non medicated and medicated. Both are usually made up of polyethylene or other polymers.
  • The non medicated IUDs are generally referred as first-generation IUDs. The copper IUDs comprise the second generation and the hormone releasing IUD the third generations IUDs.
  • Example of first-generation IUDs is Lippes loop.
  • Second generation IUDs contain copper example are Cu-T 220 C, Cu-T 380 A or Ag, nova T, multiload devices such as ML-Cu-250, ML-Cu-375.
  • Examples of third generation IUDs are progestasert and levonorgestrel.
  • IUD causes a foreign body reaction in the uterus causing cellular and biochemical changes in the endometrium and uterine fluids, which impair the viability of gamete and reduce its chances of fertilization. Along with this copper also affect the sperm motility. Hormone releasing IUD increases the viscosity of the cervical mucus and thereby prevent sperm from entering the cervix.
  • The planned parenthood federation of America ( PPFA ) has described the ideal IUD candidate as a woman:-
  • Who has borne at least 1 child.
  • Has no history of pelvic disease.
  • Has normal menstrual periods.
  • Is willing to check IUD tail.
  • Is in a monogamous relationship.
  • Has access to follow up and treatment of potential problems.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient has injury in lateral white column of spinal cord on the right side at C4 segment of spinal cord. Patient lost the sensation of fine touch, pressure, vibration, proprioception. The limb probably affected in this case is
questions.solution:
• Dorsal column medial leminiscus (DCML) pathway carries following sensations
    • Fine touch,
    • Tactile localization and discrimination
    • Vibration and pressure
    • Proprioception
    • Kinesthetic sensation
    • Stereognosis
  • The spatial orientation of fibers in the spinal cord from medial to lateral is sacral, lumbar, thoracic, cervical.
  • As shown in the figure the lateral fibers are cut probably the thoracic and cervical fibers are damaged on the right side of the spinal cord.
  • The right side of the spinal cord carries DCML tract sensation of the right side as this tract crosses in the brain stem. It carries same side fibres.
  • So right spinal cord thoracic and cervical fibers are damaged that leads to loss of DCML tract sensation of right side.
  • Upper limb fibers are supplied by C5 to T1 segments of the spinal cord. Upper limb fibers are likely to be damaged.

KEY TAKE AWAYS: The orientation of fibres in dorsal column - sacral to cervical(medial to lateral) and in lateral and anterior column - cervical to sacral(medial to lateral)

Tag: Sensory tracts

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the that program?
questions.solution:
The National Quality Assurance Standards (NQAS) are a set of standards for public health facilities in India that aim to improve the quality of healthcare:

  • Purpose

The NQAS program was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2013 to improve the quality and credibility of public hospitals.The program's goal is to instill a culture of quality and safety in health systems.

  • Standards

The NQAS standards are based on global best practices and are aligned with national and international benchmarks.The standards are used to assess and certify the quality of public health facilities in eight areas, including patient rights, clinical care, and infection control.

  • Accreditation

The NQAS is accredited by the International Society for Quality in Healthcare (ISQua).

  • Certification process

To apply for national certification, a facility must first be state certified and consistently score highly on assessments.

  • Benefits

The NQAS program provides quality services to patients and healthcare providers. It also helps public health laboratories demonstrate competency and maintain and improve quality standards.

Reference:- National Quality Assurance Standards | National Health Systems Resource Centre [Internet].

Available from: https://qps.nhsrcindia.org/national-quality-assurance-standards

questions.text: Identify the normal osmolarity of fluid marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
• The fluid marked with an arrow is interstitial fluid. The fluid red in color is plasma. These two together form extracellular fluid. The fluid inside the cells is intracellular fluid.
  • All these fluids have nearly similar osmolarity.
  • Normal plasma osmolarity is 290 mosm/kg.
    Approx 270 mosm/kg by Na+, Cl-, HCO3-, remaining 20 mosm/kg by glucose and urea, approx 2 mosm/kg by plasma proteins due to lesser no. of particles.
  • In the interstitial fluid there is no plasma proteins, but it contributes to very less osmolarity.
  • So plasma, interstitial fluid and intracellular fluid osmolality is same that is nearly 290 mosm/kg.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Total body water = ECF + ICF

ECF= Plasma volume + intestinal fluid

Normally TBW = 42L, ICF-28L, ECF-14L

Tag: Plasma proteins

questions.text: Identify the protein marked with an arrow in the figure that helps in calcium absorption from intestine
questions.solution:
• Calbindin - It is calcium binding protein. It binds with calcium ion in the intestinal epithelial cell, so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.
  • Option A - PMCA1b - plasma membrane calcium ATPase. It helps the calcium to enter in the blood stream from the basolateral surface via active transport mechanism.
  • Option B - NCX1 - Na+/Ca+ exchanger - It is found on the basolateral membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells. Here it exchanges Na+ and calcium in opposite direction.
  • Option C - TRPV6 - transient receptor potential vanilloid type 6 - Ca2+ is taken up into the body across the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells via TRPV6 channels.
  • Calbindin - It is calcium binding protein. It binds with calcium ion in the intestinal epithelial cell, so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.

Tag: calcium homeostasis

questions.text: Match the following of Demography cycle:
questions.solution:
There is a demographic cycle of 5 stages through which a nation passes.

FIRST STAGE (HIGH STATIONARY):- It is characterised by high birth rate and high death rate which cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

SECOND STAGE (EARLY EXPANDING):- The death rate begins to decline while the birth rate remains unchanged.

THIRD STAGE (LATE EXPANDING):- Death rate declines still further and the birth rate tends to fall. The population continues to grow because births exceed deaths. India has entered this phase.

FOURTH STAGE (LOW STATIONARY):- Low birth rate and low death rate with the result that the population becomes stationary.

FIFTH STAGE (DECLINING):- Population begins to decline because birth rate is lower that death rate.

Tag line:- Moderate

questions.text: Which of the findings in the child shown at right would support a diagnosis of kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
Kwashiorkor is caused by inadequate protein intake in the presence of fair to good energy (calorie) intake. Typical findings in a patient with Kwashiorkor include abdominal and peripheral edema (note the swollen belly and legs of the child) caused largely by a decreased serum albumin concentration.

Anorexia is almost always present. Weight for height can be normal.

Treatment includes a diet adequate in calories and protein.

choices.text: Expiratory splitting with inspiratory increase (e.g., RBBB)

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the given heart sound splitting pattern Below is a depiction of heart sounds during inspiration and expiration:
questions.solution:
• Option A (Normal heart sound): In normal physiology, S2 splits during inspiration due to delayed closure of the pulmonary valve, but the split narrows or disappears during expiration.
  • Option B (Atrial septal defect): Fixed splitting of S2 is characteristic of ASD, where the split remains unchanged during both inspiration and expiration. This results from chronic left-to-right shunting and constant volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle.
  • Option C (Reversed splitting): Seen in conditions like left bundle branch block (LBBB) or severe aortic stenosis, where P2 precedes A2, and the split is heard best during expiration.
  • Option D (Expiratory splitting with inspiratory increase): This occurs in right bundle branch block (RBBB) or pulmonary artery dilation, where the split widens further during inspiration. 

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Normal splitting: Inspiration increases the A2-P2 interval due to delayed P2.
  • Fixed splitting: Characteristic of ASD, unaffected by respiratory phases.
  • Reversed splitting: P2 precedes A2; seen in LBBB or aortic stenosis.
  • Widened splitting with inspiratory increase: Seen in RBBB or pulmonary artery abnormalities

questions.text: Identify the diagram showing three dimensional structure of specific Protein.
questions.solution:
Shown is a ribbon diagram tracing the polypeptide backbone of myoglobin. The color of the polypeptide chain is graded along the visible spectrum from blue (N-terminal) to tan (C-terminal). The heme prosthetic group is red.

The α-helical regions are designated A through H. The distal (E7) and proximal (F8) histidine residues are highlighted in blue and orange, respectively.

It Contains eight α-helices connected by loops, forming a compact structure. Includes a single heme group for oxygen storage. Lacks Quaternary Structure.

Option A) Albumin - Globular protein with a predominantly α-helical structure.Consists of 585 amino acids in a single polypeptide chain folded into a compact, globular form.Stabilized by disulfide bonds and hydrophobic interactions. NO heme Group. Lacks quaternary structure (monomeric).

Option B) Collagen - Fibrous protein with a unique triple-helix structure. Each helix is composed of repeating Gly-X-Y triplets (where X and Y are often proline and hydroxyproline). The three helices are tightly wound, stabilized by hydrogen bonds. Long, rigid, and rope-like structure. Primarily found in extracellular matrices; not globular.

Option D) Hemoglobin - Globular protein with a quaternary structure comprising four polypeptide chains (two α and two β subunits in adults). Each subunit contains a heme group with an iron ion capable of binding oxygen. Stabilized by non-covalent interactions between subunits. Cooperative binding of oxygen (allosteric regulation). Changes in conformation between oxygenated and deoxygenated states (T and R states).

questions.text:
The figure below represents pathological changes seen in asthmatic airways compared to normal airways.

Based on the figure, which of the following changes is NOT commonly associated with asthma?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Incorrect): Smooth muscle constriction is a hallmark feature of asthma, contributing to airway narrowing.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Increased mucus secretion due to hyperplasia of goblet cells is a common finding in asthmatic airways.
  • Option C (Correct): Alveolar wall destruction is typically seen in emphysema, not asthma. Asthma primarily affects the bronchi and bronchioles.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Submucosal thickening caused by edema and cellular infiltration is a typical finding in asthma.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Asthma: Characterized by smooth muscle constriction, mucus hypersecretion, submucosal thickening, epithelial disruption, and vascular proliferation.
  2. Emphysema: Alveolar wall destruction, not typically seen in asthma.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG tracing shown below?
questions.solution:
Right bundle branch block - features

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • RSR pattern in V1-V3
  • Wide slurred S waves in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6)

Left Bundle branch block - features

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • Absent Q wave in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5, V6)
  • Tall, monomorphic R wave in lateral leads
  • Deep S wave in V1 and V2

choices.text: Immune complex deposition in small vessels
Calcification and thrombosis of small and medium-sized vessels

questions.text: The image below represents calciphylaxis in a patient undergoing peritoneal dialysis. Which of the following is the primary pathophysiological mechanism involved in the development of calciphylaxis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Incorrect): Immune complex deposition is associated with vasculitis, not calciphylaxis.
  • Option B (Correct): Calciphylaxis is caused by calcification and thrombosis of small and medium-sized vessels, leading to ischemia and necrosis of the overlying skin and soft tissue.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Endothelial damage due to hyperglycemia is related to diabetic vasculopathy, not calciphylaxis.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Vasculitis involves inflammation of vessel walls, whereas calciphylaxis is non-inflammatory vascular calcification and thrombosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pathophysiology: Calciphylaxis results from vascular calcification and subsequent thrombosis in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), especially those on dialysis.
  • Risk Factors: Includes hyperphosphatemia, hypercalcemia, vitamin D analog use, and anticoagulant therapy (e.g., warfarin).
  • Clinical Features: Painful nodules progressing to necrotic ulcers, often on the trunk or extremities.
  • Management: Involves addressing underlying metabolic disturbances, discontinuing warfarin, and considering therapies like hyperbaric oxygen and intravenous sodium thiosulfate.

questions.text: Which genetic defect leads to deposition of trace element in cornea as shown in above image?
questions.solution:
Image showing Kayser Fischer ring, golden brown deposit at the level of the Descemet's membrane of the cornea which is seen due to copper deposition in condition like Wilson Disease.

In Wilson disease, a mutation in the gene for a copper-binding P-type ATPase (ATP7B protein) blocks the excretion of excess copper in the bile. As a consequence, copper accumulates in the liver, brain, kidney, and red blood cells.

Option B) Mutation in ATP7A is seen in Menke's Disease where copper deficiency is seen.

Option C) Rising levels of copper within the liver apparently interferes with the incorporation of this metal into newly synthesized ceruloplasmin polypeptides (apoceruloplasm) leading to a fall in plasma ceruloplasmin levels.

If left untreated, patients suffering from this form of copper toxicity may develop hemolytic anemia or chronic liver disease (cirrhosis and hepatitis), while the accumulation of copper in the basal ganglia can lead to neurologic symptoms.

Option D) Wilson disease having copper toxicity/accumulation can be treated by limiting the dietary intake of copper while concurrently depleting any excess copper already present by the regular administration of Penicillamine, a copper chelating agent that is excreted in the urine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wilson Disease (ATP7B gene mutation) causes copper accumulation and deposition in the cornea, leading to the Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • It results from impaired copper excretion in bile and is treated with dietary copper restriction and chelation therapy (e.g., Penicillamine).

choices.text: Linear IgG deposition along the glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: The image below demonstrates the pathognomonic biopsy finding in a patient diagnosed with IgA nephropathy. Which of the following is the MOST characteristic feature of this disease?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Incorrect): Linear IgG deposition is characteristic of anti-glomerular basement membrane disease (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome).
  • Option B (Incorrect): Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Option C (Correct): The hallmark of IgA nephropathy is mesangial IgA deposits, often codominant with other immunoglobulins (e.g., IgG or C3), as observed on immunofluorescence in kidney biopsy specimens.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Wire-loop lesions are characteristic of lupus nephritis.

Key Takeaways:

  1. IgA Nephropathy: Characterized by mesangial deposition of IgA, which is identified on immunofluorescence microscopy.
  2. Clinical Features: Episodic hematuria, often following upper respiratory infections, with a male predominance and peak incidence in the second and third decades of life.
  3. Histology: Light microscopy may reveal diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN), segmental sclerosis, or crescent formation in rapidly progressive cases.
  4. Diagnosis: Confirmed via renal biopsy showing dominant IgA deposits in the mesangium.

questions.text: Above image showing behavioral disturbances including self mutilation in X linked disorders of Purine Catabolism. Identify the correct Statement.
questions.solution:
X Linked disorder of purine Catabolism with behaviour disturbances is most likely Lesch Nyhan Syndrome. It is associated with virtually complete deficiency of HGPRT enzyme. It will results in an inability to salvage Hypoxanthine or guanine from which excessive amount of Uric acid produced.

Lack of salvage pathway, leads to increased PRPP levels and decreased IMP GMP level. So low level of inhibitor and high substrate level will increased de novo purine synthesis. The combination of decreased purine utilization and increased purine synthesis will results in increased purine degradation and uric acid production.

choices.text: Oral Fluconazole 400mg on day 1 followed by 200mg/day for 14-21 days

questions.text:
A HIV patient presented with fever, odynophagia and dysphagia for 10 days. CD4 count is 112. Upper GI was done which shows the following findings

The treatment of the condition is?
questions.solution:
Endoscopy shows features of candida esophagitis showing white plaques and exudates.

OPTION A- Ganciclovir 5mg/kg iv 12hourly and valganciclovir (900 mg orally every 12 h) is mainstay of treatment for CMV esophagitis.

OPTION B- Oral fluconazole (400 mg on the first day, followed by 200 mg daily) for 14-21 days is the preferred treatment for oesophageal candidiasis.

OPTION C- Poorly responsive patients or those who cannot swallow medications can be treated with an intravenous echinocandin.

OPTION D- Oral fluconazole (400 mg on the first day, followed by 200 mg daily) for 14-21 days is the preferred treatment for oesophageal candidiasis

KEY TAKEAWAY- If oral thrush is present, empirical therapy is appropriate, but co-infection is common, and persistent symptoms should lead to prompt endoscopy with biopsy, which is the most useful diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: In the Transamination reaction identify the product X & Y
questions.solution:
In transamination reactions, Enzyme Aminiotransferase converts Aspartate to Oxaloacetate simultaneously Alpha Keto glutarate converts into glutamate. In this reaction aspartate loses its Amino group by Transamination to form oxaloacetate.

Glutamate is converted to alpha ketoglutarate by transamination or through oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase.

L-Aspartate+α-Ketoglutarate ↔ Oxaloacetate+Glutamate

SGOT/AST requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), a derivative of vitamin B6, as a coenzyme for its transaminase activity

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents with morning stiffness lasting more than one-hour, joint swelling, and pain involving her wrists, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Physical examination reveals symmetric joint swelling and tenderness. An X-ray of the hands shown below:

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Correct): Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the small joints, including the wrists, MCP, and PIP joints. Radiographic findings such as joint space narrowing, erosions, and periarticular osteopenia are characteristic.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Osteoarthritis typically involves the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and shows joint space narrowing with osteophyte formation rather than erosions.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Psoriatic arthritis can involve the PIP joints but is often associated with "pencil-in-cup" deformities and asymmetric joint involvement.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Gout usually involves the first metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra) and is characterized by tophi and punched-out erosions with overhanging edges on X-ray.

Key Points:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, particularly involving the small joints.
  • Radiographic findings include joint space loss, marginal erosions, and soft tissue swelling.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are essential to prevent joint damage.

questions.text: Above image is of child suffering from dry skin, Pigmentation due to UV rays. Which mechanism of DNA Repair is defective in these case scenario?
questions.solution:
Image showing with child suffering from skin freckling, dryness and Pigmentation due to UV rays more likely having Xeroderma Pigmentosum. In XP, cells can not repair the damaged DNA resulting in extensive accumulation of mutation and consequently early skin cancers.

XP can be caused by defect in genes that code for the XP proteins required for Nucleotide excision repair of UV damage in human. A UV specific Endonuclease recognize the bulky dimers and cleaves the damaged strand. A short oligonucleotide containing the dimer is excised leaving gap in DNA strand. This gap is filled in using a DNA Pol I and DNA Ligase.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female presents with Raynaud's phenomenon, skin tightening over her fingers, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, she has taut, shiny skin on her hands and fingers (sclerodactyly). Nailfold videocapillaroscopy shows dilated capillaries, microhaemorrhages, and areas of capillary loss with neoangiogenesis as shown below:

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Correct): Systemic sclerosis is associated with microvascular changes such as nailfold capillary alterations, including dilated capillaries, microhemorrhages, and capillary loss. These findings correlate with Raynaud's phenomenon and skin fibrosis, hallmark features of systemic sclerosis.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Dermatomyositis can involve periungual capillary changes but lacks the progressive capillary loss and fibrosis seen in systemic sclerosis.
  • Option C (Incorrect): MCTD may include Raynaud’s phenomenon, but the capillary alterations are less severe and not as characteristic as in systemic sclerosis.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects joints and does not involve the capillary alterations seen in systemic sclerosis.

Key Points:

  • Systemic sclerosis is characterized by vascular damage, autoimmunity, and tissue fibrosis.
  • Nailfold capillaroscopy is a noninvasive tool to identify microvascular changes typical of systemic sclerosis, including dilated capillaries, microhemorrhages, and capillary dropout.
  • Classification into limited or diffuse forms depends on the extent of skin and organ involvement.

questions.text: Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Cutis Hyperelastica is group of connective tissue disorder with principle clinical feature - Hyperextensibility of Skin. It is also called as Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. Other signs are abnormal tissue fragility and increased joint mobility.



Option B)

Deletions in the elastin gene (located at chromosome 7q11.23) have been found in approximately 90% of subjects with the Williams-Beuren syndrome, a developmental disorder affecting connective tissue and the central nervous system.

The mutations affect the synthesis of elastin, and probably play a causative role in the supravalvular aortic stenosis often found in this condition

Option C)

Marfan syndrome is a relatively prevalent inherited disease affecting connective tissue; it is inherited as an Autosomal dominant trait. It affects the eyes (eg, causing dislocation of the lens, known as ectopia lentis), the skeletal system (most patients are tall and exhibit long digits [arachnodactyly] and hyperextensibility of the joints), and the cardiovascular system (eg, causing weakness of the aortic media, leading to dilatation of the ascending aorta).

Most cases are caused by mutations in the gene (on chromosome 15) for fibrillin-1. This results in abnormal fibrillin and/or lower amounts being deposite in the ECM.

Since the mutation interferes with the normal binding of fibrillin-1 to the cytokine transforming growth factor β (TGF-β), Marfan syndrome causes disturbances in TGF-β signaling.

Option D)

In epidermolysis bullosa, the skin breaks and blisters as result of minor trauma. The dystrophic form of the disease is due to mutations in COL7A1, which affect the structure of type VII collagen. This collagen forms delicate fibrils that anchor the basal lamina to collagen fibrils in the dermis. These anchoring fibrils have been shown to be markedly reduce in dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, probably resulting in the Blistering.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents following findings on fundoscopic examination:
He has a history of chronic renal failure and a systolic blood pressure of 220 mmHg.
questions.solution:
• Option A (Hypertensive retinopathy): This is characterized by fundoscopic findings such as blurred optic disc margins, hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots (nerve fiber layer infarcts), and exudates. The history of severe hypertension (systolic BP of 220 mmHg) and chronic renal failure supports this diagnosis.
  • Option B (Diabetic retinopathy): Although this condition also presents with retinal hemorrhages and exudates, it is typically associated with microaneurysms, neovascularization, or macular edema in a patient with diabetes, which is not mentioned here.
  • Option C (CRVO): Central retinal vein occlusion can present with "blood and thunder" appearance, including retinal hemorrhages and optic disc edema, but it is not typically associated with cotton-wool spots or severe hypertension.
  • Option D (Retinal detachment): This condition typically presents with symptoms like flashes, floaters, and a curtain-like vision loss, which are not described in this case.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Hypertensive retinopathy is often seen in patients with severe hypertension and can involve optic disc edema, hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, and exudates.
  • Chronic renal failure is a common comorbidity due to systemic vascular damage from long-standing hypertension.

questions.text: Match The following
questions.solution:
Enzymes & its role mentioned in above table are part of DNA Replication.

Option A ) Topoisomerases → 1. Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding

  • During DNA replication, as helicase unwinds the double-stranded DNA, it causes torsional strain and supercoiling ahead of the replication fork.

Topoisomerases resolve this strain by cutting one (Topoisomerase I) or both (Topoisomerase II) strands of the DNA, allowing it to unwind and relieve the stress, and then resealing the strands.

Option b) DNA primase → 3. Initiates synthesis of RNA primers

  • DNA polymerases cannot initiate DNA synthesis on their own because they need a free 3'-OH group to add nucleotides.

DNA primase, an RNA polymerase, synthesizes short RNA primers complementary to the DNA template, providing the starting point for DNA polymerases.

Option c) Helicase → 2. ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA

  • DNA helicase is an ATP-dependent motor protein that unwinds the double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between base pairs.
  • This unwinding creates single-stranded templates for DNA synthesis. Helicase activity is essential for advancing the replication fork.

Option d) DNA polymerases → 4. Deoxynucleotide polymerization

  • DNA polymerases are the enzymes responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands by adding deoxynucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs) to the growing chain.
  • They work in a 5' to 3' direction, using the RNA primer to start synthesis and the DNA template strand to ensure complementary base pairing.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with chronic lower back pain and stiffness that improves with exercise but worsens with rest. He also reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour. Physical examination reveals limited lumbar spine mobility and tenderness over the sacroiliac joints. AP pelvis radiograph shows following:

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Correct): Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton. Key features include chronic back pain, morning stiffness, improvement with exercise, and reduced spinal mobility. Sacroiliitis is often present.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Osteoarthritis typically causes mechanical pain that worsens with activity and is less likely to involve prolonged morning stiffness.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects peripheral joints and does not commonly involve the axial skeleton.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread pain and fatigue but does not cause inflammatory back pain or sacroiliitis.

Key Points:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with HLA-B27 and inflammation of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Radiographic findings include sacroiliitis and syndesmophyte formation.
  • Treatment focuses on NSAIDs, biologics (e.g., TNF inhibitors), and physical therapy.

questions.text: Identify the probable cause of above shown Abnormal pattern of Electrophoresis of serum sample.
questions.solution:
The presence of an M band (monoclonal band) in the serum protein electrophoresis indicates a monoclonal gammopathy, which is characteristic of Multiple Myeloma. This abnormal pattern is caused by the excessive production of a single type of immunoglobulin (IgA or IgG) the gamma region (monoclonal protein, or M protein) by clonal plasma cells. It also diagnosed by presence of Bence Jones Proteins in urine.

Option A) Nephrotic Syndrome

In nephrotic syndrome, the electrophoresis pattern typically shows decreased albumin levels and increased alpha-2 globulin and beta globulin levels due to selective protein loss in the urine. An M band is not characteristic.

Option B) Cirrhosis of Liver

Cirrhosis shows a polyclonal increase in gamma globulins (broad gamma region), not a discrete M band.

Option D) Antitrypsin Deficiency

This condition primarily affects the alpha-1 globulin region (reduced or absent alpha-1 band), but it does not cause an M band.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female presents with violaceous, raised, and indurated plaques around the nose, eyes, and cheeks as shown in the image.

She also reports fatigue, dry cough, and shortness of breath.
Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Correct): Lupus pernio is a chronic skin manifestation of sarcoidosis, characterized by violaceous, indurated plaques around the nose, eyes, and cheeks. It is strongly associated with pulmonary involvement and chronic disease.
  • Option B (Incorrect): SLE can cause a malar rash, but it is typically erythematous, non-indurated, and spares the nasal folds.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Rosacea causes facial erythema and telangiectasia but does not produce indurated plaques or systemic involvement.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Discoid lupus erythematosus causes scarring plaques but does not involve the violaceous induration seen in lupus pernio.

Key Points:

  • Lupus pernio is a characteristic skin finding in sarcoidosis.
  • Associated symptoms, such as fatigue, cough, and shortness of breath, suggest systemic involvement, particularly in the lungs.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy showing noncaseating granulomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a CT scan for abdominal pain, which reveals a 3 cm well-circumscribed renal mass. A renal biopsy is performed, and histological examination reveals a tumor composed of small, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders. The cells are arranged in a tubulopapillary pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis of the renal mass?
questions.solution:
A) Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type): Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can have a clear cell morphology, but it typically has more nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

B) Angiomyolipoma: Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle cells, and fat cells, which is not consistent with the histological description.

C) Papillary adenoma: Papillary adenoma is a small, benign tumor that can have a papillary architecture, but it typically has a more complex morphology and can have nuclear atypia.

D) Oncocytoma: Oncocytoma is a benign tumor composed of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders, which is consistent with the histological description.

Key Takeaways:

  • Benign renal epithelial neoplasms characterized by large round eosinophilic cells packed with mitochondria.
  • Renal oncocytoma are benign renal oncocytic neoplasms.
  • Cells are packed with mitochondria under electron microscopy.
  • Often possess pathogenic mitochondrial mutations; it is suggested that the defective mitochondria activates a metabolic checkpoint leading to autophagy impairment and mitochondrial accumulation and that this acts as tumor suppressive mechanism limiting tumor progression
  • Essential to differentiate from mimicker oncocytic renal cell carcinoma entities.
  • Multiple tumors can be associated with syndromic conditions.

choices.text: Initiation of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) therapy

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with progressive vision loss in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination reveals scattered hemorrhages, yellow exudates, and neovascularization originating from the optic disc.

Which of the following is the MOST APPROPRIATE management step?
questions.solution:
• Option C (Correct): Neovascularization of the optic disc in diabetic retinopathy indicates proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires urgent panretinal laser photocoagulation to prevent further vision loss.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Observation without treatment would lead to worsening of the condition due to ongoing neovascular proliferation and risk of complications like vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Anti-VEGF therapy is effective in some cases but is often combined with or followed by panretinal laser photocoagulation for long-term stabilization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Cataract surgery addresses lens opacity and is unrelated to the retinal changes seen in diabetic retinopathy.

Key Points:

  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is characterized by neovascularization, which increases the risk of vision-threatening complications.
  • Panretinal laser photocoagulation is a standard treatment to regress neovascularization.
  • Early diagnosis and management are critical to preserving vision in diabetic retinopathy.

choices.text: They are indicative of a malignant tumor
They are indicative of a benign tumor
They are diagnostic of a Leydig cell tumor
They have no significance in the diagnosis or prognosis of the tumor

questions.text: 50-year-old man undergoes orchiectomy for a testicular tumor. Histopathological examination reveals a Leydig cell tumor with characteristic crystalloids of Reinke. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the significance of crystalloids of Reinke in this case?
questions.solution:
A) They are indicative of a malignant tumor: This statement is incorrect. Crystalloids of Reinke are not indicative of malignancy.

B) They are indicative of a benign tumor: This statement is incorrect. While Leydig cell tumors are often benign, crystalloids of Reinke are not specifically indicative of benignity.

C) They are diagnostic of a Leydig cell tumor: This statement is correct. Crystalloids of Reinke are a characteristic feature of Leydig cell tumors.

D) They have no significance in the diagnosis or prognosis of the tumor: This statement is incorrect. Crystalloids of Reinke are an important diagnostic feature of Leydig cell tumors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Crystalloids of Reinke are rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions which can be found in Leydig cells of the testes
  • Crystalloids of Reinke are a characteristic feature of Leydig cell tumors.
  • They are an important diagnostic feature that can help distinguish Leydig cell tumors from other types of testicular tumors.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female presents with fatigue, pallor, and mild jaundice. Laboratory findings reveal severe anemia with a high mean corpuscular volume (MCV). A peripheral blood smear shows:

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear, often due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic, hypochromic red cells rather than macrocytes.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Thalassemia causes microcytic anemia and does not present with macroovalocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Anemia of chronic disease usually causes normocytic or microcytic anemia, not the findings seen in megaloblastic anemia.

Key Points:

  • Peripheral smear findings of macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are hallmarks of megaloblastic anemia.
  • Common causes include vitamin B12 deficiency (e.g., pernicious anemia) and folate deficiency.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with serum B12, folate levels, and bone marrow analysis if needed.

choices.text: Release of histamine from mast cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain, a rash on her cheeks, and fatigue. She mentions that these symptoms have worsened over the past few months. Upon examination, you note a butterfly-shaped rash on her face and swelling in multiple joints. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) Direct cytotoxicity by T cells

  • Direct cytotoxicity by T cells is associated with hypersensitivity type 4 (delayed-type hypersensitivity) rather than type 3. In this case, the symptoms and laboratory findings do not indicate a T cell-mediated mechanism.

B) Immune complex deposition in tissues

  • The patient's symptoms, including joint pain and a facial rash, along with the presence of ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies, suggest a condition like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is associated with the formation of immune complexes that deposit in various tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.

C) Release of histamine from mast cell

  • The release of histamine from mast cells is characteristic of hypersensitivity type 1 (immediate hypersensitivity) reactions. The clinical findings do not support this mechanism.

D) Autoantibody production causing cellular lysis

  • While autoantibodies can cause cellular damage, the mechanism described in this case aligns more closely with immune complex deposition rather than direct lysis of cells.

Key Takeaway:

  • In this case, the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are indicative of a condition related to hypersensitivity type 3, likely systemic lupus erythematosus, characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in tissues.
  • This leads to inflammation and tissue damage, highlighting the importance of recognizing the clinical manifestations and underlying mechanisms of type 3 hypersensitivity for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with a painless ulcer on his genitalia that has been present for 2 weeks. Examination reveals a firm, nontender ulcer with clean edges and induration at the base.
There is no discharge, and regional lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option C (Correct): Primary syphilis presents with a firm, nontender chancre at the site of Treponema pallidum inoculation. The chancre is typically painless and accompanied by regional lymphadenopathy.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Herpes simplex virus infection causes multiple painful vesicles or ulcers, often associated with systemic symptoms such as fever.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as painful genital ulcers with soft edges and significant suppurative lymphadenopathy.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Lymphogranuloma venereum presents with a small, painless ulcer followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

Key Points:

  • The classic painless, firm chancre is the hallmark of primary syphilis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with dark-field microscopy or serologic tests (e.g., RPR, VDRL, or treponemal-specific tests).
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with penicillin prevent progression to secondary and tertiary syphilis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has experienced worsening fatigue for the past 5 months. On physical examination, he is afebrile and has a pulse of 91/min, respirations of 18/min, and blood pressure of 105/60 mm Hg. There is no organomegaly. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, hematocrit of 18.3%, MCV of 99 μm3, platelet count of 250,000/mm3, and WBC count of 7800/mm3. The reticulocyte concentration is 3.9%. No fibrin split products are detected, and direct and indirect Coombs test results are negative. A bone marrow biopsy specimen shows marked erythroid hyperplasia. Which of the following conditions best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) Aplastic anemia typically presents with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cell types) and a hypocellular bone marrow, which is not seen in this case.

B) Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically presents with a positive direct Coombs test result and evidence of hemolysis, such as elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and indirect bilirubin, which is not seen in this case.

C) Chronic blood loss

  • The patient's presentation with worsening fatigue, low hemoglobin (5.9 g/dL) and hematocrit (18.3%), and a positive stool sample for occult blood suggests chronic blood loss.
  • The marked reticulocytosis and marrow hyperplasia indicate that the marrow is responding to a decrease in RBCs. The reticulocytes are larger RBCs that slightly increase the MCV.

D) Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with a low MCV (microcytic anemia) and low serum iron and ferritin levels, which is not seen in this case.

Key Takeaway:

The key findings that point towards chronic blood loss include:

  • Low hemoglobin and hematocrit, indicating anemia.
  • Positive stool sample for occult blood, indicating gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Marked erythroid hyperplasia on bone marrow biopsy, indicating a compensatory response to chronic blood loss.
  • Normal platelet count and WBC count, which makes thrombocytopenia or leukopenia less likely.
  • Negative direct and indirect Coombs test results, which makes autoimmune hemolytic anemia less likely.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with fever and an itchy rash. Examination reveals vesicles on an erythematous base, umbilicated vesicles, and crusted lesions as shown in image below.
Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Varicella (chickenpox) is characterized by a vesicular rash that appears in "crops," with lesions in various stages of evolution, including vesicles, pustules, and crusts. This is a hallmark finding.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Measles presents with a maculopapular rash starting on the face and spreading caudally, without vesicles or lesions in different stages of evolution.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Hand, foot, and mouth disease causes vesicular lesions localized to the hands, feet, and oral mucosa, not a generalized rash with crusted lesions.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Impetigo presents with honey-colored crusts but lacks vesicles on an erythematous base and lesions in multiple stages of evolution.

Key Points:

  • Varicella is a viral illness caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), often affecting children.
  • The rash evolves from macules to papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts, often described as a "dewdrop on a rose petal" appearance.
  • Vaccination is the primary preventive measure, and antiviral treatment (e.g., acyclovir) is reserved for severe cases or immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman has noticed an enlarging mass in her left breast for the past 2 years. The physician palpates a 4-cm firm mass. Following biopsy, a simple mastectomy is performed with axillary lymph node sampling. On gross sectioning, the mass has a soft, tan, fleshy surface. Histologically, the mass is composed of large cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. There is a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor, and the tumor has a discrete, noninfiltrative border. No axillary node metastases are present. The tumor cells are triple negative, for HER2, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PR). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Colloid carcinoma (also known as mucinous carcinoma) is characterized by the presence of abundant extracellular mucin, which is not mentioned in the description.

B) Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, but it typically has a more infiltrative growth pattern and may have a more variable receptor status.

C) Infiltrating lobular carcinoma is characterized by a more diffuse, infiltrative growth pattern, and often has a positive receptor status.

D) Medullary carcinoma is a rare subtype of breast cancer that typically presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass. The tumor cells are large and have vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. A distinctive feature of medullary carcinoma is the presence of a marked lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor.

Other characteristic features of medullary carcinoma include:

  • A discrete, non-infiltrative border
  • Triple-negative receptor status (i.e., negative for HER2, estrogen receptor, and progesterone receptor)
  • Absence of axillary node metastases

Key takeaways:

  • Medullary carcinomas account for about 1% to 5% of all breast carcinomas. They tend to occur in women at younger ages than do most other breast cancers.
  • Despite poor prognostic indicators (such as absence of HER2, ER, and PR), medullary carcinomas have a better prognosis than most other breast cancers.
  • Perhaps the infiltrating lymphocytes are a helpful immune response.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male with AIDS presents with progressive visual loss and floaters in his right eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disk swelling.

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS. It is characterized by retinal hemorrhages, optic disk swelling, and necrosis, often in the peripheral retina, as seen in this case.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Toxoplasma chorioretinitis typically presents with focal necrotizing lesions and severe vitreous inflammation, unlike the arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Herpes simplex virus retinitis (acute retinal necrosis) presents with severe retinal necrosis and vitreitis but lacks the characteristic CMV findings.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Syphilitic uveitis causes inflammation of the anterior or posterior uveal structures, often without hemorrhages or arcuate retinitis.

Key Points:

  • CMV retinitis occurs in patients with advanced immunosuppression (CD4 count <50 cells/μL).
  • Symptoms include painless visual loss, floaters, and scotomata.
  • Treatment includes antiviral agents such as ganciclovir or valganciclovir.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with no previous illnesses has been bothered by progressive hoarseness, shortness of breath, and stridor for the past 3 weeks. On physical examination, he has a firm, large, tender mass involving the entire right thyroid lobe. CT scan shows extension of this mass posterior to the trachea and into the upper mediastinum. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass is done, and microscopically shows pleomorphic spindle cells. The mass is noted at surgery to have infiltrated the adjacent skeletal muscle. Four of seven cervical lymph nodes have metastases. Pulmonary metastases also are identified on a chest radiograph. Which of the following neoplasms is most likely to be present in this man?
questions.solution:
A) The clinical presentation and histological findings are consistent with anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid gland.

  • Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare and aggressive type of thyroid cancer that typically presents with a rapidly growing, firm, and tender mass in the thyroid gland.
  • The tumor often extends beyond the thyroid gland and invades adjacent structures, such as the trachea, esophagus, and skeletal muscle.
  • The histological findings of pleomorphic spindle cells, which are characteristic of anaplastic carcinoma, are consistent with this diagnosis.
  • Additionally, the presence of lymph node metastases and pulmonary metastases further supports the diagnosis of anaplastic carcinoma.

B) Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a more slowly growing, encapsulated mass, and the histological findings are typically characterized by follicular architecture and capsular or vascular invasion.

C) Medullary carcinoma typically presents with a more slowly growing, firm mass, and the histological findings are typically characterized by spindle-shaped cells and amyloid deposition.

D) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid gland is a rare condition that typically presents with a rapidly growing mass, but the histological findings are typically characterized by a lymphoid infiltrate, rather than pleomorphic spindle cells.

Key takeaways:


Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: sarcomatoid(Malignant spindle cell) architecture and central zone of necrosis.


Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: pleomorphic tumor cells infiltrating skeletal muscle bundles

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with mild fever and a bright red rash on both cheeks as shown in the image.

The rash is non-tender and not pruritic. Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is caused by Parvovirus B19. The "slapped-cheek" rash is a hallmark feature, often followed by a reticulated rash on the trunk and limbs.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox, characterized by vesicular lesions in various stages of evolution, not the slapped-cheek appearance.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Measles presents with a maculopapular rash starting on the face and spreading caudally, accompanied by Koplik spots, not the bright red facial rash.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Coxsackievirus A is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease, which presents with vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and oral mucosa.

Key Points:

  • Erythema infectiosum is a common childhood viral exanthem caused by Parvovirus B19.
  • The rash often follows mild systemic symptoms like fever and malaise.
  • Parvovirus B19 can cause transient aplastic crises in patients with hemolytic anemias or hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman has had a light brown nodule on her left shin for the past year. On examination it is a 0.7-cm firm, nontender nodule. It is excised and on microscopic examination consists of a localized, dermal, spindle cell proliferation with overlying epidermal hyperplasia and downward elongation of hyperpigmented rete ridges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. A) The clinical and histological features described are consistent with a dermatofibroma.

Clinical features:

  • A firm, nontender nodule on the shin
  • Light brown color
  • Size: 0.7 cm

Histological features:

  • Localized, dermal, spindle cell proliferation
  • Overlying epidermal hyperplasia
  • Downward elongation of hyperpigmented rete ridges

B) Leiomyoma: A smooth muscle tumor that typically presents as a painful nodule.

C) Merkel cell carcinoma: A rare, aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that typically presents as a rapidly growing, firm nodule.

D) Neurofibroma: A benign nerve sheath tumor that typically presents as a soft, painless nodule.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dermatofibromas are benign, fibrohistiocytic tumors that typically present as firm, painless nodules on the extremities.
  • They are often pigmented and can be mistaken for melanocytic nevi.
  • It could be a localized response to trauma.
  • The malignant counterpart that grows larger and is more aggressive is the dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male with a history of leprosy presents with painful, erythematous nodules on his legs and arms. Some lesions are pustular.

He also reports fever and joint pain. Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY underlying condition?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is a Type 2 leprosy reaction seen in patients with lepromatous leprosy. It is an immune complex-mediated inflammatory reaction causing painful, erythematous nodules, often with systemic symptoms such as fever and arthralgia. Pustular lesions may also develop in severe cases.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, which presents with plaques or ulcerative lesions, not the nodular lesions seen in ENL.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Sweet's syndrome is an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis that causes tender plaques or nodules but is not associated with leprosy.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Vasculitis can present with painful skin lesions, but it usually involves purpura or ulcers, not pustular nodules.

Key Points:

  • ENL is a systemic inflammatory complication of lepromatous leprosy, often requiring corticosteroids or thalidomide for management.
  • It is important to distinguish ENL from other skin and systemic conditions to initiate appropriate treatment.
  • Diagnosis of leprosy and its reactions often requires clinical findings, biopsy, and acid-fast bacilli detection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes liver resection for a suspected liver tumor. Histological examination reveals a tumor composed of hepatocytes with marked steatosis and a characteristic "map-like" pattern of fibrosis. Which of the following liver tumors is most likely to exhibit this histological pattern?
questions.solution:
A) Hepatocellular adenoma: Hepatocellular adenoma is a benign liver tumor that typically exhibits a homogeneous pattern of hepatocytes without significant fibrosis.

B) Focal nodular hyperplasia: Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver tumor that typically exhibits a characteristic "map-like" pattern of fibrosis and marked steatosis.

C) Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma is a malignant liver tumor that typically exhibits a trabecular or pseudoglandular pattern of growth without significant fibrosis.

D) Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma: Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma is a subtype of hepatocellular adenoma that typically exhibits a mixed inflammatory infiltrate and a homogeneous pattern of hepatocytes without significant fibrosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver tumor that typically occurs in young women.
  • Majority are solitary and have a central scar on imaging and gross examination
  • Classic histologic features include fibrous septa, nodules of hepatocytes, abnormal thick walled vessels, bile ductular reaction and chronic inflammation
  • Glutamine synthetase demonstrates characteristic map-like staining by immunohistochemistry.

Characteristic map-like staining pattern of focal nodular hyperplasia with glutamine synthetase immunohistochemistry.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with dysuria and purulent urethral discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals gram-negative bacteria as shown in figure below.

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that often appears intracellularly within neutrophils on Gram stain. It is a common cause of urethritis with purulent discharge in men.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis but does not show up on Gram stain because it is an obligate intracellular organism.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, cannot be visualized on Gram stain and requires dark-field microscopy or serologic testing.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Mycoplasma genitalium lacks a cell wall and cannot be visualized on Gram stain.

Key Points:

  • A Gram stain showing gram-negative intracellular diplococci is diagnostic for gonococcal urethritis.
  • Coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatisis common; hence, empirical treatment often includes antibiotics effective against both pathogens (e.g., ceftriaxone and doxycycline).
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are critical to prevent complications such as epididymitis or disseminated gonococcal infection.

choices.text: Hyperplastic epithelial cells with hobnail appearance

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a family history of ADPKD undergoes a renal biopsy. Histological examination reveals numerous cysts of varying sizes, lined by which of the following types of epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
A) Flat epithelial cells: Flat epithelial cells are typically seen in simple renal cysts.

B) Cuboidal epithelial cells: Cuboidal epithelial cells are typically seen in renal tubules and collecting ducts.

C) Columnar epithelial cells: Columnar epithelial cells are typically seen in the renal pelvis and ureters.

D) Hyperplastic epithelial cells with hobnail appearance: Hyperplastic epithelial cells with a hobnail appearance are characteristic of ADPKD, and are thought to contribute to the development of cysts.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Hyperplastic epithelial cells with a hobnail appearance are characteristic of ADPKD, and are thought to contribute to the development of cysts.
  2. Histological examination is essential for diagnosing ADPKD, as it allows for the identification of characteristic hyperplastic epithelial cells.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents with fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and weight loss. He recently returned from a trip to an endemic region. An abdominal CT scan reveals a large abscess in the right lobe of the liver.

Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option C (Correct): Amebic liver abscess, caused by Entamoeba histolytica, typically presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and a single abscess in the right lobe of the liver on imaging. It is common in individuals who have traveled to or reside in endemic areas.
  • Option A (Incorrect): Pyogenic liver abscess is usually polymicrobial and often associated with biliary tract disease. It tends to present with multiple smaller abscesses rather than a single large one.
  • Option B (Incorrect): Hydatid cysts, caused by Echinococcus species, present as well-defined cystic lesions, often with characteristic daughter cysts, not the solid appearance of an abscess.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Hepatocellular carcinoma is associated with risk factors such as cirrhosis and hepatitis. It presents as a solid mass rather than an abscess.

Key Points:

  • Amebic liver abscess is diagnosed by imaging (CT or ultrasound) and confirmed by serologic testing for histolytica.
  • Management includes metronidazole as the first-line treatment, followed by a luminal agent to eradicate intestinal colonization.
  • Aspiration of the abscess is generally unnecessary unless there is no response to medical therapy or risk of rupture.

choices.text: Typical of mucinous adenocarcinoma with excellent prognosis
Indicative of primary ovarian mucinous carcinoma with poor prognosis
A benign finding with no clinical significance

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a complex ovarian mass showing signet ring cell morphology. Which of the following is most characteristic of signet ring cell appearance in ovarian tumors?
questions.solution:
Option A) Typical of mucinous adenocarcinoma with excellent prognosis

  • Signet ring cells in mucinous tumors actually indicate:
    • Aggressive behavior
    • Poor differentiation
    • Typically associated with worse prognosis
  • Not an excellent prognosis
  • Mucin-filled cells push nucleus to periphery
  • Often indicate more advanced disease stage

Option B) Pathognomonic of metastatic gastric cancer

  • Signet ring cells are most characteristic of:
    • Metastatic gastric adenocarcinoma
    • Commonly spread to ovaries
    • Known as Krukenberg tumor
  • Distinctive cellular morphology
  • Mucin-filled cytoplasm pushes nucleus to cell periphery
  • Highly aggressive metastatic pattern
  • Requires careful differential diagnosis

Option C) Indicative of primary ovarian mucinous carcinoma with poor prognosis

  • PARTIALLY CORRECT
  • Signet ring cells in primary ovarian mucinous carcinoma:
    • Do indicate poor prognosis
    • Associated with aggressive behavior
    • Suggest high-grade malignancy
  • However, more likely to be metastatic origin

Option D) A benign finding with no clinical significance

  • Signet ring cells ALWAYS indicate:
    • Malignant potential
    • Aggressive cellular behavior
    • Need for comprehensive evaluation
  • Significant clinical concern
  • Requires immediate diagnostic workup
  • Associated with potential metastatic disease

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Signet ring cells typically suggest metastatic gastric cancer
  2. Characterized by mucin-filled cytoplasm pushing nucleus peripherally
  3. Highly aggressive cellular morphology
  4. Requires careful differential diagnosis
  5. Often indicates metastatic rather than primary ovarian origin

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with cyclical fever, chills, and headache after returning from a trip to a malaria-endemic region. A thin blood smear reveals young trophozoites within red blood cells, with amoeboid cytoplasm and Schuffner's dots.


Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Option B (Correct): Plasmodium vivax is characterized by young trophozoites with an amoeboid appearance, Schüffner's dots, and preference for infecting reticulocytes (younger red blood cells). It commonly presents with cyclical fever every 48 hours (tertian fever).
  • Option A (Incorrect): Plasmodium falciparum typically shows multiple ring forms per red blood cell and does not exhibit Schüffner's dots. It also infects red blood cells of all ages.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Plasmodium malariae has a characteristic "band form" trophozoite and a 72-hour fever cycle (quartan fever).
  • Option D (Incorrect): Plasmodium ovale also shows Schüffner's dots but is less common than vivax and typically found in specific geographic regions, such as sub-Saharan Africa.

Key Points:

  • Thin and thick blood smears remain the gold standard for malaria diagnosis.
  • P. vivax and P. ovale infections require treatment with primaquine to eradicate hypnozoites in the liver, in addition to antimalarials for the blood-stage infection.
  • Clinical suspicion is critical in patients presenting with fever and a travel history to endemic regions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has developed areas of scaling skin over the past month. On physical examination there are 1- to 3-cm light pink plaques covered with silvery scale on her arms and torso. A punch biopsy of one lesion examined microscopically shows keratinocyte nuclei retained within cells in the stratum corneum. Which of the following descriptive terms best applies to this microscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Option A) Acanthosis refers to epidermal hyperplasia, in which the thickness of the entire epidermis is increased.

Option B) Dyskeratosis refers to premature keratinization below the stratum granulosum.

Option C) Hyperkeratosis is increased thickness of stratum corneum with abnormal keratin.

Option D) The microscopic finding of keratinocyte nuclei retained within cells in the stratum corneum is characteristic of parakeratosis.

  • Parakeratosis is a type of dyskeratosis, which refers to the abnormal retention of nuclei in keratinocytes.
  • In parakeratosis, the nuclei are retained within the cells in the stratum corneum, which is the outermost layer of the epidermis.
  • The clinical presentation of light pink plaques covered with silvery scale on the arms and torso is consistent with psoriasis, a chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  • Psoriasis is characterized by parakeratosis, as well as other histological features such as acanthosis and spongiosis.

Key Takeaway: The lesions are those of psoriasis, driven by T lymphocyte elaboration of cytokines driving cellular proliferation so that the normal sequence of keratinocyte maturation is disrupted.

choices.text: V wave - Represents atrial filling during ventricular systole, accentuated in tricuspid regurgitation
A wave - Represents right atrial contraction, accentuated due to reduced right ventricular compliance
C wave - Reflects early systolic increase in right atrial pressure as the tricuspid valve bulges into the atrium
Y descent - Corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after tricuspid valve opening, blunted in tricuspid stenosis

questions.text: The image below shows a jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveform and heart sounds in a patient with reduced right ventricular compliance. Identify the prominent waveform feature labeled "A" and its clinical significance.
questions.solution:
• Option A (Incorrect): The V wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound (S2). It is not the labeled waveform here.
  • Option B (Correct): The A wave reflects right atrial contraction just after the P wave on ECG and before S1. It is accentuated in conditions like reduced right ventricular compliance or pulmonary hypertension.
  • Option C (Incorrect): The C wave reflects a transient increase in right atrial pressure due to bulging of the tricuspid valve during early systole.
  • Option D (Incorrect): The Y descent corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opens. It is not labeled as "A."

Key Takeaways:

  • A wave: Reflects atrial contraction; prominent in reduced RV compliance or pulmonary hypertension.
  • C wave: Tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during early systole.
  • V wave: Atrial filling during ventricular systole; prominent in tricuspid regurgitation.
