  • Y descent: Fall in RA pressure post-tricuspid valve opening; rapid in tricuspid regurgitation, blunted in tamponade.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes a nephrectomy for a suspected renal tumor. Gross examination of the tumor reveals a 4 cm well-circumscribed mass with a grayish-white color and a solid appearance. Histological examination reveals a tumor composed of cells with a low nuclear grade and a solid, alveolar architecture. The cells are cuboidal to polygonal in shape and have regular, small central nuclei, scanty cytoplasm and no atypia. What is the most likely diagnosis of the renal tumor?
questions.solution:
A) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.

B) Papillary renal cell carcinoma: Papillary renal cell carcinoma is a subtype of renal cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary architecture and cells with a high nuclear grade.

C) Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is a subtype of renal cell carcinoma characterized by cells with a pale, reticular cytoplasm and a distinct cell border.

D) Renal adenoma: Renal adenoma is a benign tumor of the kidney, characterized by cells with a low nuclear grade and a solid, alveolar architecture.

Key Takeaways:

  • Benign papillary or tubulopapillary, low nuclear grade lesions of the kidney, similar in morphology to classic papillary renal cell carcinoma (PRCC); however, they lack fibrous capsules and are ≤ 15 mm
  • Prevalent in damaged and injured kidneys
    • Could be related to a progenitor / stem cell-like renal tubular cell population that increases upon kidney damage
  • Postulated to be precursor lesions to PRCC
    • However, the prevalence of adenoma is much higher than of carcinoma, indicating that many of them do not progress.

questions.text: The figure below represents chest CT imaging findings in interstitial lung diseases. Based on the description, identify the condition associated with subpleural reticular markings, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing with a posterior basilar predominance.
questions.solution:
• Option A (Correct): Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is associated with the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern characterized by subpleural reticular markings, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing, predominantly in the posterior basilar region.
  • Option B (Incorrect): NSIP has a more diffuse and bilateral pattern, ground-glass opacities, sparing of subpleural regions, and thickening of bronchovascular bundles.
  • Option C (Incorrect): COP typically shows patchy, migratory subpleural consolidative opacities and ground-glass opacities, with features like the reversed halo sign.
  • Option D (Incorrect): Sarcoidosis commonly presents with hilar lymphadenopathy, reticular-nodular opacities along bronchovascular bundles, and sometimes small nodules or ground-glass infiltrates.

Key Takeaways:

  1. IPF: Subpleural reticular markings, traction bronchiectasis, honeycombing, and basilar predominance are key imaging findings.
  2. NSIP: Bilateral, symmetric ground-glass opacities, sparing of subpleural regions, and bronchovascular bundle thickening.
  3. COP: Patchy subpleural consolidations and the reversed halo sign.
  4. Sarcoidosis: Mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy with reticular-nodular opacities.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman experienced severe abdominal pain with hypotension and shock that led to her death within 36 hours after onset of the pain. From the gross appearance of the mesentery, which of the following events has most likely occurred?
questions.solution:
D. Image shows the areas of white chalky deposits represent foci of fat necrosis with calcium soap formation (saponification) at the sites of lipid breakdown in the mesentery.

  • It results from the release of pancreatic lipases in a patient with acute pancreatitis.

A. Viral hepatitis does not cause necrosis in other organs and hepatocyte necrosis from viral infections occurs mainly by means of apoptosis.

B. Tuberculosis produces caseous necrosis.

C. Intestinal infarction is a form of coagulative necrosis.

choices.text: Crescent formation and rapid progression to renal failure
Nephrotic syndrome with predisposition to thrombotic complications
Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis with marked hematuria
>90% sclerotic glomeruli with end-stage renal disease (ESRD)

questions.text: The image below shows a renal biopsy from a patient with lupus nephritis, highlighting subepithelial immune deposits producing a membranous pattern. Which of the following clinical features is MOST characteristic of class V lupus nephritis?
questions.solution:
• Option A (Incorrect): Crescent formation and rapid progression to renal failure are hallmarks of class IV lupus nephritis (diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis).
  • Option B (Correct): Class V lupus nephritis (membranous lupus nephritis) is characterized by subepithelial immune deposits, leading to nephrotic syndrome and a high risk of thrombotic complications such as renal vein thrombosis.
  • Option C (Incorrect): Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis with marked hematuria is typical of class IV lupus nephritis, not class V.
  • Option D (Incorrect): >90% sclerotic glomeruli with ESRD is characteristic of class VI lupus nephritis.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Class V Lupus Nephritis: Membranous pattern with subepithelial immune deposits, nephrotic syndrome, and thrombotic risks.
  2. Management: Includes steroids, immunosuppressive agents, renin-angiotensin system inhibitors, and anticoagulation when thrombotic complications are present.
  3. Prognosis: Variable, depending on disease severity and response to therapy. Transformation to other classes or progression to ESRD may occur.
  4. Class VI Lupus Nephritis: Associated with >90% glomerular sclerosis and ESRD.

questions.text:
60 year old man presents with fatigue and weakness. Bone marrow aspirate as below:

Which stain is used for this?
questions.solution:
D. Shown image Prussian Blue iron stain on marrow aspirate from a patient with refractory anemia with ringed sideroblasts and thrombocytosis is shown. Numerous ringed sideroblasts are noted.

  • Perls' Prussian blue stain is used to detect iron accumulation in the mitochondria of erythroblasts, characteristic of ringed sideroblasts in sideroblastic anemia.

A. Reticulin stain - evaluates bone marrow fibrosis.


B. Trichrome stain - detects collagen fibers and bone marrow fibrosis.


C. Giemsa stain - used for bone marrow aspirate smears to evaluate cell morphology.

questions.text: Identify the Diagnosis in the image below
questions.solution:
Option B: Clinical symptoms may worsen as DVT propagates and involves the major proximal deep veins. Extensive DVT of the major axial deep venous channels of the lower extremity with relative sparing of collateral veins causes a condition called phlegmasia cerulea dolens

This condition is characterized by pain and pitting edema with associated cyanosis.


Option A: Cellulitis is a close differential diagnosis. It shows feature features of swelling, and erythema but not bluish discoloration

Option C: When the thrombosis extends to the collateral veins, massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema ensue, resulting in a condition known as phlegmasia alba dolens.

The affected extremity in phlegmasia alba dolens is extremely painful, edematous, and pale secondary to arterial insufficiency from dramatically elevated below-lower knee compartment pressures.

Option D: Acute ischemic limbs are usually pale

Key Take Away Point:

Both phlegmasia cerulean dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens can be complicated by venous gangrene and the need for amputation.

questions.text: Which genetic disorder is most likely to caused by following mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
• Shown pedigree chart is of mitochondrial inheritance.
  • Note that all offspring of affected female manifest disease while all offspring of affected male are normal.

Option B) Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is a disorder caused by mutation in mitochondrial DNA.

Option A: Marfan syndrome - Autosomal dominant

Option C: Wilson disease - Autosomal recessive

Option D: Lesch Nyhan syndrome - X linked recessive

questions.text: Identify the following technique shown in the image given below
questions.solution:
The image shows the drainage of the horseshoe abscess. The deep postanal space is entered, incising the anococcygeal ligament. Counter drainage incisions are made for each limb of the ischiorectal space


Option A: FiLaC - Fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC) uses a radial emitting laser to obliterate the luminal aspect of the fistula to a known depth, throughout its length.

Options B: LIFT - LIFT involves disconnection of the internal opening from the fistula tract at the level of the intersphincteric plane and removal of the residual infected glands without dividing any part of the sphincter complex. The tract is then ligated and divided, the internal part is removed and the external part of the track is curetted and drained. Hence it is a sphincter-preserving procedure, thereby maintaining continence. Systematic reviews report healing rates of 75% with little or no impairment of continence

Key TakeAway Point:

Horseshoe ischiorectal abscess can result from the lateral spread of infection originating in the deep postanal space.

If untreated, the infection can spread to the lower abdominal wall, scrotum, and perineum. Deep postanal space abscesses are almost always associated with a posterior midline fistula-in-ano, but the external openings can be located anteriorly or anywhere along the course of the horseshoe extension.

Drainage of the deep postanal space can be achieved by a midline incision between the coccyx and the anus. A fistula tract should be identified, and the lower half of the internal sphincter may be divided (Hanley procedure) or a seton placed through the fistula track.

Counter-incisions are made over the bilateral ischiorectal fossae to allow for drainage of the anterior extensions of the abscess.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a rural area of China presents with fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. He reports regular consumption of raw freshwater fish. His stool sample shows the presence of eggs that have a characteristic shouldered operculum and prominent shoulders. What is the most likely causative agent of this infection?
questions.solution:
1. (A) Schistosoma japonicum:
    • Explanation: Schistosoma japonicum is a blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis. Its eggs are oval-shaped with a lateral spine, not resembling the characteristic shouldered operculum of Clonorchis sinensis. Schistosomiasis commonly affects the mesenteric veins, causing abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly, but is not the likely cause in this scenario.
    • Key Point: Schistosoma japonicum is not associated with raw freshwater fish consumption and does not present with the same egg characteristics.
  2. (B) Fasciola hepatica:
    • Explanation: Fasciola hepatica, the liver fluke, is associated with fascioliasis. It is found in freshwater vegetation, and the eggs are oval-shaped with an operculum, but they are not shoulder-like. The disease often results in hepatomegaly, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain, similar to Clonorchis sinensis, but the egg morphology differs.
    • Key Point: Fasciola hepatica eggs lack the shouldered operculum that is characteristic of Clonorchis sinensis.
  3. (C) Clonorchis sinensis:
    • Explanation: Clonorchis sinensis is the correct answer. This liver fluke is commonly found in East Asia and is acquired by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish. The eggs of Clonorchis sinensis are distinctive with a shouldered operculum, which is seen in the stool samples. The infection causes liver damage, including jaundice and right upper quadrant pain, and can lead to cholangiocarcinoma if untreated.
    • Key Point: Clonorchis sinensis is characterized by its shouldered operculum in the eggs, and the infection is linked to the consumption of raw freshwater fish.
  4. (D) Opisthorchis felineus:
    • Explanation: Opisthorchis felineus is another liver fluke that causes opisthorchiasis. It has similar morphology to Clonorchis sinensis in terms of egg shape and can also be acquired through the consumption of raw fish. However, the geographical location and epidemiology of the disease point towards Clonorchis sinensis in this case, as Opisthorchis felineus is more commonly found in Russia and parts of Eastern Europe.
    • Key Point: Although similar to Clonorchis sinensis, Opisthorchis felineus is geographically distinct, and the correct answer is Clonorchis sinensis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clonorchis sinensis is commonly associated with the consumption of raw or undercooked freshwater fish and causes liver fluke infections.
  • The eggs of Clonorchis sinensis are distinctive, with a shouldered operculum and prominent shoulders.
  • It is crucial to differentiate between liver flukes like Clonorchis sinensis, Fasciola hepatica, and Opisthorchis felineus based on egg morphology and geographic distribution.

Reference: CDC

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes presents with severe pain and swelling in the perineal region, along with fever and an advancing erythematous rash. On examination, the area shows signs of necrosis and gas in the tissue. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fournier's gangrene is an uncommon and nasty condition characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissues of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is a form of necrotizing fasciitis


Treatment of a case of Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency. Initial management involves intravenous fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics. Urgent wide surgical excision of the dead and infected tissue is essential and the extent of the internal necrosis is typically much greater than the external appearances suggest, with extensive debridement often necessary. Urinary and fecal diversion may be necessary. Supportive care is essential because patients often become severely septic.

Option A: Fournier gangrene starts as cellulitis, but here in this image, it shows extensive necrosis. So this option is incorrect

Option C: The clinical scenario does not match that of testicular torsion - usually seen in younger individuals and acute onset of pain, redness, and erythema. However, a necrosis is unlikely.

Option D: The epididymis and testis swell and become painful. The scrotal wall, at first red, oedematous and shiny, may become adherent to the epididymis. This option does not match the given clinical scenario.

Key Take Away Point:

choices.text: Multi-organ failure due to viral spread

questions.text: A 40-year-old male traveler develops encephalitis symptoms shortly after returning from an endemic area in Asia. MRI shows brainstem involvement with a characteristic pattern of edema. Which of the following is the most likely complication in a severe case of Japanese Encephalitis?
questions.solution:
• A) Brainstem hemorrhage: While brainstem involvement is common in JE, hemorrhage is not typically a feature. The infection usually causes edema and inflammation in the brainstem rather than direct hemorrhage.
  • B) Permanent cognitive impairment: Severe cases of Japanese encephalitis can lead to long-term neurological sequelae, including permanent cognitive impairment, movement disorders, and behavioral changes. These long-term complications occur due to the virus's effects on the brainstem and cerebrum.
  • C) Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Although ARDS can complicate infections, it is not the most common complication of JE. The primary complications are neurological, and respiratory failure is a rare, secondary event.
  • D) Multi-organ failure due to viral spread: Multi-organ failure is more common in infections such as dengue or sepsis, not JE. JE primarily affects the central nervous system and does not typically lead to multi-organ failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Severe cases of Japanese Encephalitis often result in permanent cognitive impairment, movement disorders, or behavioral changes.
  • MRI findings typically show brainstem involvement and edema, especially in severe cases.
  • JE affects the central nervous system, and neurological sequelae are common in survivors.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a history of cholelithiasis presents with abdominal pain and distention. Imaging shows small bowel obstruction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: A detailed patient history (e.g., gallbladder disease) and imaging findings such as the presence of a biliary-enteric fistula on a CT scan or Rigler's triad (small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and ectopic gallstone) can help differentiate gallstone ileus from an enterolith.

However, the enteroliths are rare and close differential diagnosis.

Option B: Proximal stones can become impacted in the pylorus or proximal duodenum causing gastric outlet obstruction (Bouveret syndrome).

Option C:

Option D: The characteristic radiological sign of gallstone ileus is Rigler's triad, comprising: small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and an atypical mineral shadow on radiographs of the abdomen. The presence of two of these radiological signs has been considered pathognomonic of gallstone ileus and is encountered in 40-50% of the cases (note that pneumobilia is a common finding following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy).

Key takeaway point:

A plain abdominal radiograph shows:

  • partial or complete intestinal obstruction;
  • pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree;
  • an aberrant rim-calcified or total-calcified gallstone;
  • a change in the position of such a gallstone on serial films ('tumbling sign')

questions.text: Based on the image of MOA (Modified Oxford Agar) showing elongated colonies of Factor F2, what organism is most likely identified?
questions.solution:
• Modified Oxford Agar (MOA) is a selective medium used for the isolation of Corynebacterium species.
  • Factor F2 is a characteristic factor associated with the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae on MOA.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria and is identified by its specific growth characteristics on selective media like MOA.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B), Clostridium perfringens (Option C), and Corynebacterium ulcerans (Option D) are not specifically associated with Factor F2 on MOA.

questions.text: In what percentage of cases with perforated peptic ulcer does an erect chest radiograph reveal free gas under the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
An erect chest radiograph will reveal free gas under the diaphragm in more than 50% of cases with perforated peptic ulcers.

The image is an Erect chest radiograph showing air under the right diaphragm in a patient with a perforated duodenal ulcer.

Key TakeAway Point:

Air under the diaphragm signifies a Perforated hollow viscus.

The treatment of this condition is Immediate Exploratory Laparotomy

questions.text: Identify the organism based on the given image of a microgametocyte.
questions.solution:
The microgametocyte of Plasmodium falciparum is banana-shaped or sausage-shaped with pale blue or pink cytoplasm and a large nucleus, which is characteristic of this species.

  • P. vivax (Option B) has spherical microgametocytes with a compact, pale blue cytoplasm.
  • P. knowlesi (Option C) and P. malariae (Option D) have different morphological features in their gametocytes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. Lab results show cholestatic liver enzyme abnormalities. Abdominal ultrasound is normal, with no gallstones or bile duct dilation. ERCP shows the following finding. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
ERCP has traditionally been the gold standard for the depiction of the biliary tree and also offers the ability to perform cholangioplasty, if necessary. In practice, however,

MRCP is used before ERCP since it is non-invasive, can visualize the liver, and avoids the 10% risk of hospitalization from ERCP in primary sclerosing cholangitis patients.

MRCP (or ERCP) may demonstrate stricturing and beading of the bile ducts in PSC The image is a case of Sclerosing cholangitis in a patient with ulcerative colitis,

visualized by endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.

Key Take Away Point:

  • Important differential diagnoses are secondary sclerosing cholangitis, immunoglobulin G4 (IgG4) cholangitis, autoimmune hepatitis, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) cholangiopathy and cholangiocarcinoma.
  • The last may arise in patients with PSC and is difficult to diagnose; a high index of suspicion is required, especially in the setting of unexplained clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A lady presented with a foul smelling greyish white discharge and whiff test was positive. On examination following cells were seen as shown in the image given below. Identify the causative organism and drug of choice
questions.solution:
• Gardenella vaginalis is a species of Gram variable staining facultative anaerobic bacteria. The organisms are small non spore forming non motile coccobacilli.
  • It is a natural inhabitant in Vagina. You can get BV if too much gardenella grows.
  • Etiology is not known, but multiple sexual partners is one of the risk factors. If left untreated the infection can make you more susceptible to contracting other STIs including HIV, Chlamydia and Gonorrhea.
  • In women Gardenella can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease. Can also cause some complications in pregnancy including premature labour and delivery.
  • Treatment with metronidazole or clindamycin of both sexual partners may provide resolution of symptoms in these men.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the image. The image shows a microscopic view of macroconidia stained with lactophenol cotton blue.
questions.solution:
• A) Trichophyton rubrum: This option is incorrect. Trichophyton rubrum is another dermatophyte but does not typically produce macroconidia like Microsporum canis. T. rubrum often forms slender, cylindrical microconidia.
  • B) Microsporum canis: This is the correct answer. Microsporum canis is a dermatophyte commonly found in animals (e.g., cats and dogs). The image shows large, rough, spindle-shaped macroconidia that are characteristic of this species. It is also responsible for tinea capitis and tinea corporis.
  • C) Candida albicans: This option is incorrect. Candida albicans is a yeast and does not form macroconidia. It causes opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, and its morphology is different from that of dermatophytes like Microsporum canis.
  • D) Aspergillus fumigatus: This option is incorrect. Aspergillus fumigatus is a filamentous fungus known for its conidia (not macroconidia). It is typically associated with respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, and its conidia are round and smaller than the macroconidia of Microsporum canis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Microsporum canis is a dermatophyte known for causing superficial fungal infections such as tinea capitis and tinea corporis. It is characterized by the presence of large, rough, spindle-shaped macroconidia under the microscope.
  • The image in question shows the classic appearance of macroconidia of Microsporum canis, which are used for its identification in a laboratory setting.
  • The organism is zoonotic and can be transmitted from animals, especially cats and dogs, to humans.
  • Treatment for infections caused by Microsporum canis typically involves antifungal medications, including griseofulvin or terbinafine.

Additional Notes:

  • Tinea capitis and tinea corporis are common infections caused by Microsporum canis. Treatment may involve oral antifungal therapy for more severe cases.
  • A Wood's lamp (ultraviolet light) can sometimes be used to detect Microsporum canis on the skin, as it may fluoresce a characteristic greenish color.

Reference:

  • American Academy of Dermatology (AAD). Fungal Infections of the Skin. https://www.aad.org/

Hepatic abscess has been associated with colorectal malignant disease
In the West, malignant obstruction has become a more predominant cause

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the condition shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The image shown here is that of a pyogenic liver abscess!

Option B: Historically, untreated appendicitis was considered the most common cause of the hepatic abscess, but with the advent of antibiotics and the development of prompt and effective treatment of acute intraabdominal infections, portal venous infections of the liver have become less frequent.

Option A: Most hepatic abscesses involve the right hemiliver, accounting for about 75% of cases. The explanation for this is not known, but preferential laminar blood flow to the right side has been postulated. The left liver is involved in approximately 20% of the cases; the caudate lobe is rarely involved (5%).

Option C: Hepatic abscess has also been associated with colorectal malignant disease.

Option D: In Asia, intrahepatic stones and cholangitis (recurrent pyogenic cholangitis [RPC]; see later) are common causes, whereas in the West, malignant obstruction has become a more predominant cause.


Key TakeAway Point:


Topic: Liver abscess; Image-based

PYQ: NEET 2023; NEET 2021

questions.text: The image below shows the typical vesiculopustular rash characteristic of a viral infection. Based on the clinical features described, which disease is most likely the cause of this rash?
questions.solution:
• A) Chickenpox: Chickenpox also causes a vesicular rash, but it is typically more localized and may have a different progression (crops of lesions in various stages). Chickenpox does not cause the widespread scarring associated with smallpox.
  • B) Measles: Measles causes a characteristic maculopapular rash, not a vesiculopustular rash, and the lesions tend to appear on the face and spread down the body.
  • C) Smallpox: This image is a classic example of smallpox, as described in the WHO smallpox recognition cards. It shows the vesiculopustular rash seen after upper respiratory tract infection, with characteristic scarring, especially on the face. Smallpox had a fatality rate of up to 40%.
  • D) Herpes Simplex Virus Infection: Herpes simplex infections cause fluid-filled blisters, but these are typically localized to specific areas (such as oral or genital regions) rather than the widespread rash seen in smallpox.

questions.text: Match the following blades with their uses:
questions.solution:
Blade 11 has a pointed tip and is commonly used for precise incisions such as arteriotomy.

Blade 15 is small and curved, ideal for delicate procedures like plastic surgery. Blade 22 is larger and used for making longer, deeper incisions, such as abdominal

surgeries.

Blade 10: Has a large curved cutting edge, commonly used for skin incisions in general surgery

Key Takeaway Point:

questions.text: A patient presented with painful blisters on the trunk involving a dermatome as shown in the image. What is the most likely organism implicated in causing it
questions.solution:
The presentation of painful blisters on the trunk confined to a dermatome is characteristic of herpes zoster, also known as shingles. This condition is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which initially causes chickenpox (varicella) and later remains dormant in nerve ganglia.

Varicella zoster virus (VZV) is the correct organism implicated in causing herpes zoster. Here's why the other options are not appropriate:

  • Chickenpox (Varicella): This is caused by the same varicella-zoster virus but typically presents with a diffuse rash that is not confined to a dermatome. It usually affects children and results in widespread vesicular lesions across the body rather than localized blisters.
  • Measles: Caused by the measles virus, it presents with a widespread rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body, not confined to a dermatome, and does not involve painful blisters.
  • Molluscum contagiosum: Caused by a poxvirus, it leads to benign, non-painful, umbilicated papules, not painful blisters confined to a dermatome.
  • Thus, the most likely organism causing painful blisters on the trunk involving a dermatome is: option (D): Varicella zoster

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis shown in the post-operative image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shown here is a post-operative image of debridement done for meleney gangrene ( Necrotising soft tissue infection) of the abdominal wall.

Key Takeaway Point:

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly spreading infection that produces necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and overlying skin. It is caused by β-hemolytic streptococci and, occasionally, Staphylococcus aureus, but may take the form of a polymicrobial infection associated with other aerobic and anaerobic pathogens, including Bacteroides, Clostridium, Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella. It is termed Fournier's gangrene when it affects the perineal area and Meleney's gangrene when it involves the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Based on the image of the lesion presented, which type of dermatophyte infection is being shown in image part A ?
questions.solution:
• A) Tinea cruris:
    This infection, also known as 'jock itch,' typically affects the groin area, thighs, and buttocks, with the scrotum often spared. The image in part (A) is not characteristic of tinea cruris, which tends to have more localized involvement of the groin area.
  • B) Tinea corporis:
    Correct Answer. The lesion shown in part (A) is an annular lesion with a raised, scaly border, which is characteristic of tinea corporis (ringworm). It is caused by dermatophytes such as Microsporum species, which are shown here. This infection affects the body, including the arms, trunk, and legs.
  • C) Tinea capitis:
    Tinea capitis affects the scalp and presents with hair loss, scaling, and sometimes pustules. The lesion shown in part (A) does not have the typical features of tinea capitis.
  • D) Tinea pedis:
    Tinea pedis, or athlete's foot, affects the feet and typically involves the spaces between the toes. The annular lesion shown in part (A) is not characteristic of tinea pedis.

Key Points to Remember:

  • Tinea corporis is a superficial dermatophyte infection of the body, often presenting as an annular lesion with a scaly, raised border.
  • Dermatophytes such as Microsporum species cause tinea corporis and can sometimes fluoresce under UV light, aiding in diagnosis.
  • Tinea cruris, tinea capitis, and tinea pedis affect different body areas and have their own characteristic presentation.

Reference:

  • American Academy of Dermatology (AAD). (2021). Fungal Infections: Diagnosis and Treatment of Dermatophyte Infections. Mayo Clinic. (2020). Ringworm (Tinea corporis) Symptoms and Causes.

Reference: American Academy of Dermatology (AAD). (2021). Fungal Infections: Diagnosis and Treatment of Dermatophyte Infections.
Mayo Clinic. (2020). Ringworm (Tinea corporis) Symptoms and Causes.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presented to the vascular clinic with dull aching pain in the lower limb. He is found to have the following clinical picture. What is the clinical classification?
questions.solution:
The image shown here is Corona phlebectatica


Key Take home message:

Corona phlebectatica (malleolar fare): a fan-shaped pattern of telangiectasia on the ankle or foot. This is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

questions.text: Based on the image of nasal scrapings showing acid-fast bacilli, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Tuberculosis:
    While Mycobacterium tuberculosis also appears as acid-fast bacilli, its presence would be in lung tissue or sputum, not typically in nasal scrapings. The appearance of M. leprae in the nasal mucosa is more indicative of leprosy.
  • B) Leprosy:
    Correct Answer. The image showing acid-fast bacilli in nasal scrapings, specifically in a patient with lepromatous leprosy, points to Mycobacterium leprae. This bacterium is responsible for the chronic, progressive disease, leprosy, which often affects the nasal mucosa.
  • C) Syphilis:
    Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, does not appear as acid-fast bacilli. It is a spirochete that would require a different type of stain, such as dark-field microscopy or special serological tests.
  • D) Actinomycosis:
    Actinomyces species can form sulfur granules in infected tissues but are not acid-fast. They are Gram-positive bacteria, and their presence in nasal scrapings is not typical of actinomycosis.

Key Points to Remember:

  • Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, and nasal involvement with acid-fast bacilli is characteristic in lepromatous leprosy.
  • Acid-fast bacilli are seen with Ziehl-Neelsen stain in diseases caused by mycobacteria (e.g., leprosy and tuberculosis).
  • Leprosy typically affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes, including the nasal mucosa.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO). (2022). Leprosy and Its Diagnosis.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2021). Leprosy: Epidemiology and Diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the average duration beyond which the following complication can occur in a patient who underwent Modified radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Lymphangiosarcoma, or Stewart Treves syndrome, is a rare tumor that develops as a complication of long-standing (usually more than 10 years) lymphedema.


Clinically, the patients present with acute worsening of the edema and appearance of subcutaneous nodules that have a propensity toward hemorrhage and ulceration.

The tumor can be treated, like other sarcomas, with preoperative chemotherapy and radiation followed by surgical excision, which usually may take the form of radical amputation.

Overall, the tumor has a very poor prognosis

Key Take Away Point:

In 1948, Stewart and Treves described lymphangiosarcoma of the upper extremity in women with ipsilateral lymphedema after radical mastectomy.

Angiosarcoma is now the preferred name.

questions.text: Identify the organism associated with the histopathological features shown in the image, where portal fibrosis is observed due to granuloma formation around worm eggs in the liver.
questions.solution:
• A) Schistosoma mansoni: Correct Answer. The portal fibrosis seen in the image, caused by granulomas around the eggs of Schistosoma mansoni, is characteristic of chronic infection with this parasite. The pipe-stem fibrosis and granulomas are commonly seen in liver involvement in Schistosoma mansoni.
  • B) Schistosoma haematobium: Schistosoma haematobium causes similar granulomatous reactions but affects the bladder wall rather than the liver. Although both species belong to the same genus, the organ affected in Schistosoma haematobium is the bladder, not the liver.
  • C) Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large intestinal roundworm that causes ascariasis, leading to intestinal infections, not the granulomatous reactions seen with Schistosoma mansoni in the liver.
  • D) Strongyloides stercoralis: This parasitic infection primarily involves the intestines and can lead to a hyperinfection syndrome in immunocompromised individuals. It does not cause the characteristic granulomatous liver lesions or pipe-stem fibrosis seen with Schistosoma mansoni.

Key Takeaways:

  • Schistosoma mansoni causes portal fibrosis in the liver due to granulomas formed around deposited eggs.
  • Pipe-stem fibrosis is a hallmark of chronic Schistosoma mansoni infection.
  • Schistosoma haematobium affects the bladder wall and causes bladder fibrosis, not liver fibrosis.
  • Schistosoma species can lead to hepatosplenomegaly and ascites in severe cases due to portal hypertension.

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Schistosomiasis Overview. WHO Website.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Schistosomiasis - A Global Health Threat. CDC Website.

questions.text: Identify the grade of Renal injury in the CT image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Grade IV laceration to the posterolateral right kidney with posterolateral extravasation of contrast material.


Ket TakeAway Point:

questions.text: Based on the image shown below, which of the following parasitic infections is associated with the appearance of these proglottids (segments) and eggs in the stool?
questions.solution:
• A) Taenia solium: While Taenia solium is also a tapeworm, it is primarily transmitted through pork and has different egg and segment characteristics. The eggs and proglottids of T. solium are often smaller than those of T. saginata. T. solium can also cause cysticercosis if its eggs are ingested.
  • B) Taenia saginata: Correct. The image depicts the typical proglottids of Taenia saginata, which are larger than those of T. solium. This species is transmitted through infected beef, and infection is often asymptomatic except for the passage of large segments in the stool. Diagnosis involves identifying the segments or eggs in stool samples.
  • C) Echinococcus granulosus: Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid disease, which typically forms cysts in the liver or lungs. This infection does not produce the same segments and eggs as shown in the image.
  • D) Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma mansoni is a fluke and not a tapeworm. It produces miracidia and cercariae in the water, and its eggs are oval-shaped and distinctively different from those of Taenia. It causes schistosomiasis, which presents with symptoms like abdominal pain, blood in stools, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Key Takeaways:

  • Taenia saginata infection is typically asymptomatic but can cause discomfort when the large proglottids (segments) are passed.
  • The diagnosis of T. saginata infection is confirmed by the presence of characteristic segments and eggs in stool samples.
  • Transmission of T. saginata occurs via consumption of infected beef containing cysticerci, and proper cooking of meat is essential for prevention.

Image: [Image showing the characteristic segments (proglottids) of Taenia saginata in the stool and the appearance of its eggs.]

Reference:

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Taeniasis and Cysticercosis. CDC Website.

World Health Organization (WHO). (2022). Taenia saginata - Beef Tapeworm Infections. WHO Website
