questions.text:
Based on the image shown below, which of the following conditions is most likely to be diagnosed based on the appearance in the colon?


Image: [Image showing the characteristic appearance -yellowish-white plaques on the colon mucosa]
questions.solution:
• A) Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease characterized by continuous lesions starting from the rectum, but it does not typically show pseudomembranes. The inflammation in ulcerative colitis is more uniform and does not form the yellowish-white plaques characteristic of pseudomembranous colitis.
  • B) Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease also involves inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, but it causes patchy lesions and deep ulcers, rather than the superficial pseudomembranes seen in pseudomembranous colitis.
  • C) Pseudomembranous colitis: Correct. The image depicts pseudomembranes-yellowish-white plaques of necrotic tissue and inflammatory cells on the colon mucosa, which are a hallmark of pseudomembranous colitis. This condition is primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection, often after antibiotic therapy.
  • D) Infectious gastroenteritis: Infectious gastroenteritis may cause diarrhea and inflammation, but it does not typically produce the characteristic pseudomembranes seen in pseudomembranous colitis. The lesions are more diffuse and not localized as plaques.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pseudomembranous colitis is most commonly caused by Clostridium difficile and is characterized by yellowish-white pseudomembranes on the colonic mucosa.
  • This condition is often a result of antibiotic-associated disruption of normal gut flora, leading to overgrowth of C. difficile.
  • Early recognition of the pseudomembranes is crucial for diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Reference:

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Clostridium difficile Infection: Overview and Diagnosis. CDC Website.

American Society for Microbiology. (2023). Pseudomembranous Colitis and C. difficile Infection. ASM Website.

questions.text: A 1 month old infant presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension with the following xray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duodenal Atresia

Definition:

  • Congenital obstruction of the duodenum, typically due to a failure of recanalization.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Bilious vomiting
  • Abdominal distension

Diagnosis:

  • Prenatal: Polyhydramnios on ultrasound

Postnatal: Abdominal x-ray or upper GI series showing the "double bubble" sign


Complications:

  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte imbalances

Management:

  • Initial: Stabilisation with IV fluids and electrolyte correction
  • Definitive: Surgical repair (duodenoduodenostomy or duodenojejunostomy)

Tags:

  • TOPIC: Duodenal atresia
  • PYQ: FMGE Dec 2021

questions.text: Based on the image shown below, which of the following best describes the condition observed in the vaginal epithelial cells, where they are coated with bacteria?
questions.solution:
• A) Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis and is characterized by the presence of motile flagellates in the vaginal discharge, not clue cells. It also does not typically present with the same bacterial profile as seen in bacterial vaginosis.
  • B) Candidiasis: Candidiasis is caused by yeast, typically Candida albicans, and presents with thick, white cottage cheese-like discharge, not clue cells. There is no characteristic bacterial coating on the epithelial cells as seen in bacterial vaginosis.
  • C) Bacterial vaginosis: Correct. The image shows clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, commonly seen in bacterial vaginosis. The condition is associated with an overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic bacteria, leading to symptoms like a fishy-smelling vaginal discharge and an elevated vaginal pH.
  • D) Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID): PID is an infection of the upper reproductive organs and is not typically characterized by clue cells. It may involve symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal discharge but is not directly associated with clue cells as seen in bacterial vaginosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clue cells are a key diagnostic feature of bacterial vaginosis, where vaginal epithelial cells are covered with bacteria, especially Gardnerella vaginalis.
  • Symptoms of bacterial vaginosis include a fishy-smelling discharge, vaginal pH >4.5, and the presence of clue cells.
  • Bacterial vaginosis is primarily caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, with Gardnerella vaginalis being consistently involved.

Image:
[Image showing clue cells – vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, typical of bacterial vaginosis]

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Bacterial Vaginosis. CDC Website.
American Society for Microbiology. (2022). Bacterial Vaginosis: Diagnosis and Pathogenesis. ASM Website.

choices.text: Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate colostomy
Hightype imperforate anus, Delayed surgical correction after colostomy
Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate surgical repair (PSARP)
Hightype imperforate anus, Immediate surgical correction

questions.text: A newborn is found to have an absent anal opening. An invertogram performed after 24 hours shows the rectal gas at the level of the pubococcygeal line. What is the appropriate classification of this condition, and what is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Imperforate Anus

Incidence and Classification:

  • A congenital anomaly where the anal opening is absent or incorrectly positioned.
  • Low-type: Rectum ends below the levator ani muscle.
  • High-type: Rectum ends above the levator ani muscle.

Clinical Features:

  • Absence of Anal Opening: The most obvious sign at birth.
  • Associated Anomalies: Often occurs with other congenital defects, particularly in the sacrum, genitourinary system, and as part of VACTERL association.

Diagnosis:

  • Invertogram (24 hours post birth): Helps determine the level of the rectum in relation to the pubococcygeal line.

  • Ultrasound and MRI: Further imaging may be required to assess associated anomalies.

Management:

  • High-type: Initial colostomy to divert faecal flow, followed by Posterior Sagittal Anorectoplasty (PSARP) for definitive repair.
  • Low-type: Direct surgical correction, often without the need for a colostomy.

Surgical Procedures:

  • Posterior Sagittal Anorectoplasty (PSARP): The most common procedure used to repair both high and low anomalies.

Complications:

  • Faecal Incontinence
  • Strictures

Option A: Lowtype anomalies are managed with immediate surgical repair without the need for colostomy.

Option B: Hightype imperforate anus, Delayed surgical correction after colostomy is Correct. Hightype imperforate anus is characterised by the rectum ending above the levator ani muscle, and initial management involves colostomy to divert faecal flow, followed by definitive surgery (PSARP) at a later date.

Option C: Low Type imperforate anus, Immediate surgical repair (PSARP): This is the correct approach for low type anomalies, where the rectum is located below the pelvic floor.

Option D: Immediate surgical correction without a protective colostomy is inappropriate for hightype anomalies due to the risk of complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hightype imperforate anus requires colostomy followed by delayed definitive surgical correction.
  • Invertogram is crucial for determining the level of the anomaly and guiding management.

Tags:

  • TOPIC: Imperforate Anus
  • PYQ: FMGE Dec 2021

questions.text: Based on the image shown below, which of the following organisms is responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
• A) Trichomonas vaginalis: Correct. The image shows a pear-shaped protozoan with four flagella and an undulating membrane, which is characteristic of Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative agent of trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection.
  • B) Giardia lamblia: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan but typically appears as a kidney-shaped organism with two nuclei, which is different from the shape and structure of Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • C) Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is an amoeba, not a flagellate. It is typically seen as an irregular-shaped organism with distinct nuclei, and it causes amoebic dysentery, not trichomoniasis.
  • D) Plasmodium falciparum: Plasmodium falciparum is a protozoan that causes malaria, and it appears as ring-shaped trophozoites within red blood cells, not as a flagellated organism like Trichomonas vaginalis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan that causes trichomoniasis, characterized by its pear-shaped body, four flagella, and undulating membrane.
  • It is a common cause of vaginitis and is transmitted sexually.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2023). Trichomoniasis - Diagnosis and Treatment. CDC Website.
American Society of Microbiology. (2022). Trichomonas vaginalis: Diagnosis and Pathogenesis. ASM Website.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with pneumothorax. Which of the following is indication for surgical management?
questions.solution:
Pneumothorax and ICD insertion

  • all of the given options are indications for surgical intervention in pneumothorax.

Inserting and managing a chest drain

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease. The safest site for the insertion of a drain is in the triangle that lies:

  • anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • above the level of the nipple;
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.

  • Sterility: Maintain strict sterility throughout the procedure.
  • Anaesthesia: Ensure adequate local anaesthesia, including the pleura.
  • Dissection: Use sharp dissection for the skin and blunt dissection with artery forceps through muscle layers, aiming to avoid air entrapment.
  • Drain Placement:
    • For pneumothorax/haemothorax: Position the drain towards the apex of the lung.
    • For pleural effusion/empyema: Position the drain near the lung base. Always insert over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle below.
  • Stitching: Secure the retaining stitch; omit in empyema cases for better drainage.
  • Connection: Attach the drain to an underwater seal for a one-way valve function.
  • Post-procedure: Confirm correct drain placement with a chest X-ray; avoid clamping the drain.

Option A. First contralateral pneumothorax: Correct. The recurrence of pneumothorax on the opposite side is an indication for surgery.

Option B. Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax: Correct. Bilateral pneumothorax presents an increased risk and is often managed surgically.

Option C. Pregnancy: Correct. Pregnancy is an indication for surgical management due to the need to prevent recurrence and respiratory complications during gestation.

Option D. All of the above: Correct. Each of the above scenarios is a valid indication for surgical intervention in the case of pneumothorax.

Key points:

  • Surgical intervention is indicated for recurrent pneumothorax, bilateral involvement, or in special cases such as pregnancy. The main goal is to prevent recurrence and improve patient outcomes.

Tags:

  • Topic: Spontaneous pneumothorax
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2023; INICET NOV 2022

questions.text:
A 25-year-old patient presents with sudden onset fever, chills, muscle aches, sore throat, and a dry cough. The patient has a history of recent travel to an area with high seasonal flu activity. A sample from the respiratory tract reveals the presence of a single-stranded RNA virus with an envelope. Based on these characteristics, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?
Image is given
Identify the virus.
questions.solution:
• A) Hepatitis C virus: Hepatitis C virus is a blood-borne virus primarily affecting the liver. It does not present with flu-like symptoms such as fever, sore throat, or muscle aches.
  • B) Influenza virus: Influenza virus is a single-stranded RNA virus with an envelope. It is responsible for seasonal flu and is characterized by symptoms such as fever, chills, sore throat, muscle aches, and cough, fitting the patient's presentation.
  • C) Human papillomavirus: HPV causes warts and is associated with cancers like cervical cancer, not flu-like symptoms.
  • D) Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically causes lesions around the mouth (HSV-1) or genital area (HSV-2), but it does not present with the systemic flu-like symptoms described in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • Influenza virus is a single-stranded RNA virus with an envelope that causes flu-like symptoms, including fever, chills, sore throat, and cough.
  • Influenza outbreaks occur seasonally, and the virus is spread through respiratory droplets.

Reference:

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2022). Influenza (Flu) Symptoms & Prevention. CDC Website.https://www.cdc.gov/flu/

World Health Organization (WHO). (2023). Influenza Virus and Its Impact. WHO Website https://www.who.int/

questions.text: 8 year old male chronic smoker complains of weight loss with chronic cough and Ptosis. The X-ray given below shows the right apical mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: SVC syndrome: Causes venous distension but lacks the characteristic heart and lung findings.


Option B.Chronic smoker complains of weight loss suggest malignancy and patient also having Ptosis and arm pain suggest horner's syndrome.All findings lead to pancoast tumor.

Pancoast tumour

  • A Pancoast tumour is a tumour of the apex of the lung.
  • It is a type of lung cancer defined primarily by its location situated at the top end of either the right or left lung.
  • It typically spreads to nearby tissues such as the ribs and vertebrae.
  • Most Pancoast tumours are non-small-cell lung cancers.

  • MNEMONIC FOR HORNER SYNDROME :

Option C:


Option D: SIGNS OF PULMONARY EMBOLISM


Key points:

  • Chronic smoker complains of weight loss suggests malignancy and patient also having Ptosis and arm pain suggest Horner's syndrome.

TAGS:

  • TOPIC: Pancoast Tumor
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2023

questions.text: What does the area between the dotted lines in graph indicate?
questions.solution:
• The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows a therapeutic window.
  • It is the range of steady-state concentrations of drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.
  • Therapeutic window expresses a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.
  • The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called therapeutic ratio.
  • Mathematically, you can calculate TI by following way:
  • Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50

Where,

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.
  • The therapeutic window is the range of dosages that produces a therapeutic response without causing adverse effects.
  • 'Therapeutic window' is bounded by the dose which produces minimal therapeutic effect and the dose which produces maximal acceptable adverse effect
  • Key Takeaway
  • Therapeutic range, also called the ‘therapeutic window’ is bounded by the dose which produces minimal therapeutic effect and the dose which produces maximal acceptable adverse effect

questions.text: Kanchanben was diagnosed with lung cancer one month back, and presented with shortness of breath. On examination, the Kussmaul sign was positive. Heart sounds are distant and breath sounds appear reduced on the left side infra-scapular area. Requisition for chest X-ray is done and shown below. Comment on the diagnosis of the patient:
questions.solution:
Pericardial effusion

  • Pericardial Effusion:
    • Results from imbalance in the production and resorption of pericardial fluid.
  • Tamponade:
    • Occurs when pressure in the pericardium exceeds atrial pressure, leading to reduced venous return and compromised circulation. It can be gradual (e.g., malignancy) or acute (e.g., trauma, surgery).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Low blood pressure, raised jugular venous pressure, paradoxical pulse, and Kussmaul's sign (jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration).
  • Emergency Treatment:
    • Pericardial aspiration with a wide-bore needle temporarily relieves tamponade until further management (e.g., median sternotomy) is determined.
  • Chronic Tamponade:
    • Often due to malignancy (breast or bronchial cancer) or other conditions like uraemia or connective tissue disease. May require a pericardial window for long-term relief.


Option A: Pleural effusion: Unlikely as it doesn't explain distant heart sounds or Kussmaul sign.


Option B: Congestive heart failure: CHF presents with fluid overload but not with distant heart sounds and Kussmaul sign.


Option C: Cardiac tamponade: Correct. Distant heart sounds, Kussmaul sign, and shortness of breath are classic for cardiac tamponade, often seen in lung cancer with pericardial involvement.

Option D: SVC syndrome: Causes venous distension but lacks the characteristic heart and lung findings.


Key points:

Cardiac tamponade presents with distant heart sounds, Kussmaul sign, and shortness of breath, often due to pericardial effusion in lung cancer.

TAGS:

  • TOPIC: CARDIAC TAMPONADE
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2022

questions.text: A patient was given topical anti-glaucoma drug for several months. He presents with the features shown in the below image. Which amongst the following is the likely drug responsible for the adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• The given image is of pigmentation of iris known as heterochromia iridis. It is caused by PFG2a analogs like latanoprost.
  • Latanoprost
  • Instilled in the eye, this PGF2α derivative has shown efficacy similar to timolol (i.o.t. reduction by 25–35%) and the effect is well sustained over long-term.
  • It reduces i.o.t. in normal pressure glaucoma also.
  • Blurring of vision, increased iris pigmentation, thickening and darkening of eyelashes have occurred in some cases.
  • Macular edema can develop during treatment with any PGF2α analogue, especially in aphakic patients; a watch should be kept to detect it early.

Summary of Adverse Effects of Anti-Glaucoma medications

  • Key takeaway
  • Pigmentation of iris known as heterochromia iridis. It is caused by PFG2a analogs like latanoprost.

choices.text: Immediate surgery without further medical management

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with episodes of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. He has intermittent hypertension and has recently experienced weight loss. His biochemical tests show elevated plasma metanephrines. A CT scan reveals a well-defined adrenal mass with central necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma

  • Tumours arising from the adrenal medulla, secreting catecholamines (e.g., adrenaline, noradrenaline).
  • Symptoms: Classic triad of headache, sweating, and palpitations. Also presents with hypertension (paroxysmal or continuous).
  • Biochemical Diagnosis: Plasma or 24-hour urinary metanephrines (elevated in pheochromocytoma).
  • Imaging: CT or MRI to localise the tumour. MIBG scans if extra-adrenal or metastatic disease is suspected.
  • Preoperative Management: Alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) is necessary to prevent hypertensive crises during surgery. Beta-blockade is added if needed for tachycardia.
  • Surgical Management: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is preferred for most cases unless the tumour is large (>10 cm) or shows signs of malignancy.

Explanation of Options:

A. Incorrect. Surgery without preoperative management is dangerous due to catecholamine surges during surgery, potentially leading to hypertensive crises.

B. Correct. Preoperative alpha-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) is essential to control blood pressure and prevent intraoperative complications. After adequate blockade, surgery is safe.

C. Incorrect. Chemotherapy is not the first-line treatment for phaeochromocytoma.

D. Incorrect. Radiotherapy is not typically used in the management of phaeochromocytoma.

Key Points:

  • Classic Triad: Headache, sweating, palpitations.
  • Preoperative Alpha-Blockade: Essential for preventing complications during surgery.

Tags:

  • Topic: Pheochromocytoma
  • PYQ: NEET PG 2021; FMGE AUG 2020, DEC 2021, JUNE 2022, JAN 2023

questions.text: Identify the unknown drug A by its action on rabbit ileum in a given image below:
questions.solution:
• The given figure shows that the drug is stimulant at rabbit ileum and its stimulatory effects are not blocked by atropine.
  • So, it seems to be a directly acting stimulant like Barium chloride or calcium chloride. We can identify the nature of some drugs by their effect on rabbit ileum
  • To identify the unknown drug, First see whether the drug increases the tone (stimulant) or decreases (depressant).
  • If it is stimulant, it is likely to be acetylcholine or barium chloride. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by atropine or not. If stimulant effect is absent after atropine, the drug is acetylcholine but if it is still present, then it is directly acting drug like barium or calcium chloride.
  • If it is depressant, it is likely to be adrenaline or papaverine. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by betablocker or not. If depressant effect is absent or reduced after giving beta blocker (completely abolished by alpha plus beta blocker), the drug is adrenaline but if it is still present, then it is directly acting drug like papaverine or KCl.

Key takeaway

  • Barium chloride or calcium chloride drug is stimulant at rabbit ileum and its stimulatory effects are not blocked by atropine.

choices.text: Simple mastectomy without lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a large mass in her left breast. Mammography reveals diffuse microcalcifications consistent with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and a BRCA1 mutation is confirmed. After discussing treatment options, the patient opts for surgery. What is the most appropriate surgical treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Mastectomy Indications and Types

  • Indications for Mastectomy:
    • Large tumors relative to breast size, multicentric disease, diffuse microcalcifications, BRCA mutations, recurrence after breast-conserving surgery, and patient preference.
  • Types of Mastectomy:
    • Simple Mastectomy: Removal of breast tissue without axillary dissection.
    • Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM): Removal of breast tissue and axillary lymph nodes (levels I, II, III).
    • Radical Mastectomy (Halsted): Removal of breast tissue, pectoralis muscles, and axillary lymph nodes; rarely performed due to high morbidity.
  • Complications of Radical Mastectomy: Shoulder movement limitation, extensive upper limb lymphedema, pain, chest wall deformity.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. BCS would not be appropriate for diffuse microcalcifications indicative of DCIS, or for BRCA1-positive patients, as the risk of recurrence is higher.

Option B) Incorrect. Radical mastectomy (Halsted) involves the removal of breast tissue, pectoralis muscles, and all axillary nodes.

Option C) Correct. Modified radical mastectomy (MRM) is the appropriate treatment, as it involves mastectomy along with axillary lymph node dissection (levels I, II, and III), making it suitable for large tumors, multicentric disease, or genetic predisposition (BRCA mutations).

Option D) Incorrect. Simple mastectomy without lymph node dissection is inadequate for patients with DCIS and BRCA1 mutations, as axillary lymph node evaluation is essential.

Key Points: Modified radical mastectomy is preferred over radical mastectomy due to fewer complications and no difference in survival benefit.

Tags:

  • Topic: Mastectomy
  • PYQ: NEET 2021, FMGE DEC 2020

questions.text: A new experimental anti-arrhythmic drug is found to be effective against both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Its effect on action potential is shown in image below. The effect of this new drug is most similar to which of the following agent?
questions.solution:
• This drug is decreasing the slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blocking property) as well as increasing the action potential duration (K+ channel blocking property).
  • Thus, it exhibits the properties of class Ia anti-arrhythmic agents like quinidine.

Features of Class I Anti-arrhythmic Drugs

  • They are Na+ Channel blockers
  • Decreases Slope of Phase 0 depolarization

ECG:

  • Quinidine increases P-R and Q-T intervals and tends to broaden QRS complex.
  • Mechanism of action: Quinidine blocks myocardial Na+ channels in the open state-reduces automaticity and rate of 0 phase depolarization in a frequency dependent manner.
  • Prolongation of APD is due to K+ channel block, while lengthening of ERP is caused by its moderate effect on recovery of Na+ and K+ channels.

Key takeaway

  • This drug is decreasing the slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blocking property) as well as increasing the action potential duration (K+ channel blocking property).

choices.text: Mastectomy with a portion of the pectoralis major muscle and radiotherapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painless subareolar lump that has gradually increased in size over the past few months. There is also involvement of the nipple and areolar complex. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma of the Male Breast

  • Epidemiology: Male breast cancer is rare, accounting for less than 0.5% of breast cancer
  • Presentation: Typically presents with a painless subareolar lump. Involvement of the nipple-areolar complex and underlying pectoral muscles occurs early.
  • Treatment: Standard treatment includes mastectomy with a 2-cm margin and removal of a portion of the pectoralis major muscl Radiotherapy is recommended post-surgery. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) should be performed in node-negative patients.
  • Tamoxifen: Recommended for patients with ER-positive tumors (20 mg daily for 5 years).

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Wide local excision is not the standard treatment for male breast cancer with early nipple-areolar complex involvement.

Option B) Correct. Mastectomy with a portion of the pectoralis major muscle, followed by radiotherapy, is the standard treatment for male breast cancer involving the nipple and areolar complex. Sentinel lymph node biopsy should also be performed in node-negative patients.

Option C) Incorrect. Chemotherapy is reserved for advanced or metastatic cases.

Option D) Incorrect. Observation without intervention is not recommended for breast cancer.

Key Points: Male breast cancer often presents with subareolar lumps and early nipple involvement. The standard treatment is mastectomy with radiotherapy.

Tags:

  • Topic: Carcinoma of the Male Breast

choices.text: A: Loop diuretics, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
A: Thiazides, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.text: Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram:
questions.solution:
• A is thick ascending limb of loop of Henle; loop diuretics acts on this part.
  • B is distal convoluted tubule; thiazides act on this part.

Mechanism of actions of different diuretics agents

Thiazides

Drugs in this group include

  • Chlorthiazide,
  • Hydrochlorthiazide,
  • Benzthiazide,
  • Hydroflumethiazide,
  • Chlorthalidone,
  • Metolazone, and indapamide.

These drugs reach the lumen of nephron by secretion through organic acid transporter system.

↓

Acts by inhibiting Na+-Cl- symporter at the luminal membrane of early DT.

↓

By increasing excretion of solutes, thiazides make the urine concentrated

Key takeaway

  • Loop diuretics acts on thick ascending limb of loop of Henle and thiazides acts on distal convoluted tubule

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is diagnosed with bilateral undescended testis. Which of the following is a common long term complication if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Consequences of Undescended Testes

  • Infertility:
    • Men with undescended testes may have reduced fertility, even after orchidopexy.
    • Unilateral Cases: Infertility rate similar to the general population.
    • Late Orchidopexy (in Adults): Almost always results in infertility and azoospermia.
    • Early Surgery: Recommended to prevent degeneration of spermatogenic tissue, which starts after the second year of life.
  • Malignancy:
    • Risk of testicular cancer is 2-6 times
    • Most common type of cancer in untreated undescended testes is seminoma, with a peak incidence between ages 15-45.
    • Early detection through testicular self-examination is crucial.
  • Hernia:
    • About 90% of boys with undescended testes have a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of hernia, though not all develop a clinically apparent hernia.
  • Testicular Torsion:
    • Undescended testes have a higher risk of torsion due to developmental abnormalities between the testis and its mesentery.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele is unrelated to undescended testes and involves fluid accumulation in the scrotum.

Option B. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. While torsion is more common in undescended testes, it is not the most significant longterm complication.

Option C. Testicular cancer: Correct. There is an increased risk of developing testicular cancer in undescended testes, particularly if not corrected by early childhood.

Option D. Varicocele: Incorrect. Varicocele involves dilated veins in the scrotum and is not directly associated with undescended testes.

Key Points:

  • Undescended testes increase the risk of testicular cancer and infertility.
  • Early surgical correction (orchidopexy) reduces risks.

Tags:

  • Topic: Complications of Undescended Testes
  • PYQ: FMGE AUG 2020; JUNE 2021

questions.text: A 30 year old male, on multiple drugs for his medical condition, presents with a round macule on his right leg past 7 days. The patient gives history of similar episodes over the past 8 years which resolve spontaneously after 7-10 days. Which of the following is most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Ibuprofen is the offending agent. This is a case of fixed drug eruption.
  • The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.
  • Antibacterial sulphonamides, antibiotics, NSAID's, analgesics, and hypnotics are the most frequent causes of FDE Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology.
  • Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Option B & D: Phenytoin and carbamazepine are causes of drug-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symploms (DRESS syndrome).

Option C: Captopril, which is an ACEI, can cause anaphylactic reaction with urticaria.

  • Key takeaway
  • Ibuprofen is the offending agent for fixed drug eruption. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

questions.text: A 20 year old male complains of a dull ache in the left scrotum, especially after standing for long periods. Physical examination shows a mass resembling a "bag of worms" above the left testis, which increases with Valsalva manoeuvre. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Varicocele

  • Dilation of the pampiniform plexus veins, more common on the left side.
  • There are three theories as to the cause of varicoceles:
    • The absence or failure of the anti reflux valve usually located where the testicular vein joins the left renal vein or the inferior vena cava on the right. This causes reflux and retrograde flow in the testicular vein.
    • The 'nutcracker' effect that occurs when the left testicular vein gets trapped between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction.
    • Angulation at the junction of the left testicular vein and the left renal vein.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dull, aching pain, especially after prolonged standing; may be asymptomatic; described as feeling like a "bag of worms."

  • Diagnosis: Physical exam with Valsalva maneuver, confirmed by ultrasound showing dilated veins >3 mm.
  • Management:
    • Conservative in asymptomatic cases;
    • surgical ligation or embolization in symptomatic cases or infertility.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hydrocele: Incorrect. Hydrocele presents as a painless fluid filled sac around the testis, not a "bag of worms" appearance.

Option B. Varicocele: Correct. Varicocele involves dilated veins of the pampiniform plexus, often described as a "bag of worms" and typically worsens with standing or Valsalva maneuver.

Option C. Testicular torsion: Incorrect. Torsion presents with acute pain and high-riding testis, not a mass that feels like a "bag of worms."

Option D. Epididymal cyst: Incorrect. These cysts are typically painless and do not present with a "bag of worms" feel.

Key Points:

  • Varicocele is a common cause of male infertility and presents as a "bag of worms" on palpation.
  • Surgical treatment is considered for symptomatic relief or in cases of infertility.

Tags:

  • Topic: Varicocele
  • PYQ: FMGE DEC 2021; JUNE 2022

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug that impinges on oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the velocity of drug particles entering the upper airways
Decreases the systemic absorption of drugs

questions.text: All are correct about the below device used along with pMDI except:
questions.solution:
• The given image is of a spacer device with a face mask.
  • The spacer device is used between the PMDI (pressurized metered dose inhaler) and the patient.
  • Spacers reduce the velocity of particles entering the upper airways and the size of particles by allowing the evaporation of liquid propellant.
  • Children as young as 3 years of age are able to use a spacer device fitted with a mask.
  • Most asthma patients are now maintained on inhaled medication only. Aerosols are of two types:
    1. Use drug in solution: pressurized metered dose inhaler (MDI), nebulizers.
    2. Use drug as dry powder (DPI) spinhaler, rotahaler.
  • Pressurized metered dose inhalers use hydrofluroalkane (HFA) propellants and deliver a specified dose of the drug in spray form per actuation
  • A large volume 'spacer' (chamber interposed between the inhaler and the patient's mouth) can be used to improve drug delivery by obviating the need for precise coordination.
  • Moreover, larger particles settle on the walls of the spacer reducing the fraction that deposits in the throat and is later swallowed.
  • Local complications (candidiasis with inhaled steroids) as well as systemic exposure are reduced.

Option A & B: The above actions reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways

Option D: By reducing oropharyngeal deposition, the systemic absorption is also decreased

Key takeaway

  • Large volume 'spacer' (chamber interposed between the inhaler and the patient's mouth) can be used to improve drug delivery by obviating the need for precise coordination.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and flank pain. Imaging shows a cystic dilation at the distal end of the ureter inside the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ureterocele:
    • Cystic dilation of the distal ureter, often at the ureterovesical junction. It can cause obstruction, leading to hydronephrosis and recurrent infections.
  • Types:
    • Simple (orthotopic) and ectopic.
    • Ectopic ureteroceles are more common in duplex systems and are associated with significant clinical symptoms.
  • Symptoms:
    • Recurrent UTIs, flank pain, hematuria, or asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound or cystoscopy; may show a ballooning of the distal ureter within the bladder.
    • When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice. The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the 'cobra head' sign.

  • Management:
    • The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter.
    • Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux.
    • A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.

Option A : Vesicoureteral reflux is Incorrect. This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, but it does not present as a cystic dilation within the bladder.

Option B : Ureterocele is Correct. Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter, often visible within the bladder and associated with obstructive symptoms.

Option C : Urethral diverticulum is Incorrect. This condition involves the urethra and typically presents with dysuria, post void dribbling, or recurrent UTIs.

Option D : Bladder cystitis is Incorrect. Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder lining, not characterised by cystic dilation within the ureter.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ureterocele often presents with recurrent UTIs and may cause hydronephrosis.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with imaging studies.

Tags:

Topic: Ureterocele

Tags: FMGE Aug 2020, FMGE Dec 2020

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can result in the below condition?
questions.solution:
• Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate is known to cause blackening of tongue, dentures and stools.
  • Proposed mechanism:
    • Combines with trace amounts of sulfur in saliva and colon to form bismuth sulfide. Bismuth sulfide is a highly insoluble black salt.
    • The adverse effect is claimed to be temporary and harmless.
  • Bismuth subsalicylate
    • It is thought to act by decreasing PG synthesis in the intestinal mucosa, thereby reducing Cl¯ secretion.
    • It has some prophylactic value in travellers' diarrhoea (probably due to weak antibacterial action as well)
    • Dark stools (sometimes mistaken for melena) and black staining of the tongue in association with bismuth compounds are caused by bismuth sulfide formed in a reaction between the drug and bacterial sulfides in the GI tract.

Option A: PPIs are quite safe drugs and have diarrhea, headache and abdominal pain as adverse effects.

Omeprazole and other PPIs inhibit CYP2C19 enzyme and result in Increase/decreased activity of other drugs.

Option B: Most common side effect of sucralfate is constipation.

Option D: It is a potent inhibitor of CYP enzymes and can increase plasma

concentration of warfarin, theophylline and many other drugs.

It inhibits metabolism of estradiol and increases serum prolactin levels on long term use, thus can cause gynaecomastia (in males) and galactorrhoea (in females).

Key Takeaway

  • Black staining of the tongue in association with bismuth compounds are caused by bismuth sulphide.

choices.text: Laparoscopy or thoracoscopy for diagnosis and repair

questions.text: A 35 year old male is involved in a high speed car accident and presents with shortness of breath and abdominal pain. Chest Xray shows a raised hemidiaphragm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Laparoscopy or thoracoscopy for diagnosis and repair is Correct. These procedures allow direct visualisation of the diaphragm and facilitate definitive repair.

Traumatic Diaphragmatic Injury: A Comprehensive Overview


Summary of Traumatic Diaphragmatic Injury

Traumatic diaphragmatic injury is a serious condition that occurs when the diaphragm, the muscle separating the chest and abdomen, is damaged. It is often caused by blunt or penetrating trauma.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma: The most common cause, typically resulting from motor vehicle accidents or falls.
  • Penetrating trauma: Such as stab wounds or gunshots.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: May show signs of diaphragmatic herniation, like a raised hemidiaphragm or air-fluid levels in the chest.
    • CT scan: Provides more detailed imaging but can sometimes miss small tears.
    • Laparoscopy/thoracoscopy: The gold standard for diagnosis and management, allowing direct visualisation of the injury.

Management:

  • Surgical repair: Early intervention is crucial to prevent complications.
    • Timing: Prompt surgical repair is recommended.
    • Approach: Laparoscopy or thoracoscopy, depending on the injury's location and the patient's condition.
    • Technique: Primary repair is often sufficient, but larger defects may require mesh reinforcement.

Complications:

  • Herniation: Abdominal contents can herniate into the thoracic cavity, leading to bowel obstruction or respiratory distress.
  • Strangulation

Option A: Delayed surgical repair is Often required but usually guided by laparoscopy or thoracoscopy to confirm the diagnosis and guide repair.

Option B: Observation and repeat imaging is Not appropriate due to the risk of herniation and strangulation of abdominal contents.

Option C: Chest tube insertion is avoided. It's Necessary only if there is an associated pneumothorax, but does not address the underlying diaphragmatic injury.

Option D: Laparoscopy or thoracoscopy for diagnosis and repair is Correct. These procedures allow direct visualisation of the diaphragm and facilitate definitive repair.

Key Takeaway:

Diaphragmatic injury:

More common on the left side.

C/F :

  • Breathlessness.
  • Bowel sounds in thoracic cavity.

Mx :

  • Never insert a chest tube blindly.
  • Laparotomy (Preferred).
  • Bowel reduction + repair diaphragm + chest tube insertion.

Tags:

  • Topic: Traumatic Diaphragmatic Injury - Diagnosis and Management
  • PYQ: INICET May 2022 | Inicet July 2021 | Inicet Nov 2021

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed the below brownish pigmented lesions. On inquiring, the patient admitted to chronic laxative use. Which of the following laxative is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
• Regular use of senna for more than 6-12 months as purgative causes colonic atony and mucosal pigmentation (melanosis) as shown in the image.
  • Purgative abuse
  • Purgatives are often self-prescribed and taken without consulting a physician.
  • Drawbacks of purgative abuse are:
  • Fluid and electrolyte imbalance, especially hypokalaemia.
  • Steatorrhoea, malabsorption syndrome.
  • Protein losing enteropathy.
  • Spastic colitis
  • Senna
  • The active principle of Senna stimulates the myenteric plexus to increase peristalsis and decrease segmentation.
  • They also promote secretion and inhibit salt and water absorption in the colon.
  • Skin rashes, fixed drug eruption are the occasional adverse effects.
  • Regular use for 4–12 months causes colonic atony and mucosal pigmentation (melanosis).

Options B, C & D: All of them are not associated with melanosis coli.

Key Takeaway

  • Chronic use of anthraquinone derivatives (like senna and cascara) may lead to melanosis coli (brown pigmentation of colon)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a pearly nodule on his face. He has a long history of sun exposure due to outdoor work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma

  • Slow-growing: Locally invasive, rarely metastasizes.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic UVR exposure, light skin, age 40-80, and living near the equator.
  • Most Common Subtypes: Nodular (90% of cases) with a pearly surface and telangiectasia.
  • High-Risk BCC: Large tumours(>2cm ), recurrent, or located near high-risk areas like eyes and nose. (tear area)Can invade bone or cause severe local destruction.

  • Management: Surgical excision (Mohs' micrographic surgery for high-risk cases).
  • Tumour and surrounding surgical margins should always be assessed and marked under loupe magnification, the latter varying between 2 and 15 mm depending on the macroscopic variant.
  • Radiotherapy in elderly patients or for inoperable cases. Topical therapies like 5-fluorouracil or imiquimod for superficial BCC.

Explanation:

Option A) Melanoma usually presents as a pigmented lesion with asymmetry, irregular borders, and rapid growth.

Option B) Correct. BCC is characterised by a pearly, translucent nodule with overlying telangiectasia, often associated with chronic sun exposure.

Option C) SCC usually presents as a more ulcerative lesion with scaling, often related to chronic inflammation or sun damage.


Option D) Actinic Keratosis presents as rough, scaly patches, and is considered a precursor to SCC.

Key Points:

Nodular BCC is the most common subtype (90%). UVR is the strongest risk factor.

TAGS:

  • Topic: Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • PYQ: FMGE JUNE 2021; NEET PG 2022; INICET NOV 2023

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with suicidal overdose of a drug. Patient is flabby and comatose with shallow failing respiration. The BP of the person is 80/40 mm Hg and the patient had following lesion which is shown in the below image. Based on these features likely poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• The clinical features points towards poisoning caused by CNS depressant drug. The figure shows the characteristic barbiturate blisters. So it is phenobarbitone poisoning
  • Adverse effects and contraindications
  • Due to the long duration of action, hangover is common. Barbiturates can cause distortion of sleep architecture by decreasing the duration of REM and stage 3 and 4 sleep and increasing the duration of stage 2 sleep.
  • Learning and memory impairment can occur.
  • Idiosyncratic reaction resulting in excitement can occur in some patients.
  • These are absolutely contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria (because porphyrin synthesis is increased due to induction of d-ALA synthase; rate limiting enzyme in porphyrin synthesis, by barbiturates).
  • At high doses, acute poisoning may occur (manifests as coma, depressed respiration, hypotension, cardiovascular collapse and barbiturate blisters).
  • Treatment
    1. Gastric lavage; leave a suspension of activated charcoal in the stomach to prevent absorption of the drug from intestines.
    2. Supportive measures: such as, patent airway, assisted respiration, oxygen, maintenance of blood volume by fluid infusion and use of vasopressors- dopamine may be preferred for its renal vasodilating action.
    3. Alkaline diuresis: with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg i.v. with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long-acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
    4. Haemodialysis and haemoperfusion (through a column of activated charcoal or other adsorbants) is highly effective in removing long-acting as well as short-acting barbiturates. There is no specific antidote for barbiturates.

Key takeaway

  • At high doses, acute barbitutare poisoning may occur (manifests as coma, depressed respiration, hypotension, cardiovascular collapse and barbiturate blisters).

questions.text: A G2P0A1 woman presents after a spontaneous abortion, 2 months back with complaints of bleeding per vaginum & lower abdominal pain. Her UPT comes out to be strongly positive & she denies having any physical intimacy with her male counterpart for past 2 months. On getting a Sonography done, ovaries show this appearance. What do you think is the most likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The positive UPT and ovarian appearance could indicate theca lutein cysts, which are commonly associated with molar pregnancies. The absence of intimacy suggests that persistent trophoblastic tissue is producing high levels of hCG, typical of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), such as a molar pregnancy.

b. Incomplete abortion
(Incorrect): Incomplete abortion may cause bleeding, but it is less likely here given the positive UPT and ovarian findings suggestive of trophoblastic disease. Moreover, 2 months have passed since the initial abortion.

c. Uterine arteriovenous malformation
(Incorrect): While uterine arteriovenous malformation can cause abnormal bleeding, it would not explain the positive UPT or the ovarian findings seen on sonography.

d. Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia
(Incorrect): This condition may cause abnormal bleeding but is not associated with a positive pregnancy test or ovarian changes seen on ultrasound.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Theca luetin cysts are more common with a complete mole
  • Likely result from ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels.
  • Remember that hCG and luteinizing hormone share the same receptor, and both can stimulate the theca layer that surrounds follicles.
  • Because theca-lutein cysts regress following pregnancy evacuation and subsequent hCG level decline, expectant management is preferred.

Tags:

  • Topic: Hydatidiform mole
  • PYQ INICET NOV 2021

questions.text: For a woman treated with lithium during pregnancy, the fetus should be tested for which of the following teratogenic effect?
questions.solution:
• Lithium has documented evidence of teratogenicity which comprises mainly of the cardiac anomalies. Ebstein's anomaly (congenital heart disease) is seen with lithium use in pregnancy.
  • Adverse effects of Lithium
  • Nausea, vomiting and mild diarrhoea occur initially, can be minimized by starting at lower doses.
  • Thirst and polyuria are experienced by most patients
  • Fine tremors may occur even at therapeutic concentrations.
  • CNS toxicity manifests as plasma concentration rises producing coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, hyper-reflexia
  • Lithium
  • It is a small monovalent cation that does not produce any acute effect but on prolonged use, acts as a mood stabilizer.

Effects of lithium

(Mnemonic = Lithium)

L - Leucocytes

I - Increased

T - Tremors (Most common side effect)

H - Hypothyroidism

I - Increased Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, can be used for the treatment

of SIADH.

U - Increase Urine Amiloride is DOC for lithium induced DI.

M should be avoided in expectant Mothers as it causes Ebstein’s anomaly

Key Takeaway

  • Lithium has documented evidence of teratogenicity which comprises mainly of the cardiac anomalies. Ebstein's anomaly (congenital heart disease) is seen with lithium use in pregnancy.

choices.text: These are homologous to Cowper's glands in males
Located in the deep perineal pouch
Exudes alkaline secretions to lubricate vagina
Duct is lined by columnar epithelium

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the structure (pointed with an arrow) in the figure shown below, except:
questions.solution:
Bartholin's glands are not located in the deep perineal pouch; they are situated in the superficial perineal pouch. Specifically, they are located bilaterally at the posterior aspect of the vaginal opening, just beneath the vaginal mucosa.

a. These are homologous to Cowper's glands in males
Correct. Bartholin's glands in females are homologous to Cowper's glands (bulbourethral glands) in males. Both sets of glands are involved in the production of lubricating secretions.

c. Exudes alkaline secretions to lubricate vagina
Correct. Bartholin's glands secrete a mucous, alkaline fluid that helps to lubricate the vaginal vestibule during sexual arousal.

d. Duct is lined by columnar epithelium
which facilitates the secretion and transport of the glandular fluid to the vaginal vestibule.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Bartholin glands are located in superficial perineal pouch.

Homologous to Cowpers gland.

Secrete alkaline secretions.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a painful skin lesion on his right leg. He was admitted to the hospital 6 days ago for new-onset atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. He was discharged on warfarin but was not given IV heparin in the hospital. His heart rate has been well controlled since starting metoprolol and warfarin. Blood pressure is 114/78 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical examination, there is a large, dark skin lesion on his right leg that is cool to the touch (see image). What decrease in which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• Warfarin induced bleeding & ecchymosis is the result of decrease of levels of protein C
  • Adverse effects of warfarin
  • Bleeding as a result of extension of the desired pharmacological action is the most important problem causing ecchymosis, epistaxis, hematuria, bleeding in the g.i.t.
  • Intracranial or other internal haemorrhages may even be fatal.
  • Bleeding is more likely if therapy is not properly monitored, or when the International normalized ratio (INR) exceeds 4, or interacting drugs/contraindications are present.
  • Treatment
  • Withhold the anticoagulant.
  • Give fresh blood transfusion; this supplies readymade clotting factors and replenishes lost blood. Alternatively fresh frozen plasma may be used as a source of clotting factors.
  • Give vit K1 which is the specific antidote, but it takes 6-24 hours for the clotting factors to be resynthesized and released in the blood after vit K administration.

Key Takeaway

  • Warfarin induced bleeding & ecchymosis is the result of decrease of levels of protein C
  • Bleeding is the most common adverse effect of all anticoagulants.
  • If a patient develops bleeding due to overdose of warfarin, four factor concentrate or fresh frozen plasma (to supply clotting factors) is the treatment of choice but specific antidote is vitamin K1 (but the action will be delayed).

questions.text: A 17 year old girl presents to gynaec OPD with pain and swelling in the genital region. On examination, the swelling is red, tender to touch and looks like the image given below. Which of the following is the most common causative agent of this pathology?
questions.solution:
• The girl is suffering from Bartholin's abscess.
  • Escherichia coli was the most common (43.6%), followed by aureus (6.4%), group B streptococci (4.8%), and Enterococcus spp.(4.8%). Less than 10% of cases were polymicrobial in origin.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

E. coli is most common organism associated with bartholin abscess.

questions.text: The clinical presentation in the below image is likely caused by which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
• The image shows deep vein thrombosis of the right leg. The swelling and change in colour points towards DVT.
  • Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator with estrogen agonist action on bone and liver. It is associated with increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and is contraindicated in adults with a history of venous thromboembolism
  • Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator with estrogen agonist action on bone and liver. It is associated with 3-fold increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and is contraindicated in adults with a history of venous thromboembolism.
  • Other Side effects
  • Hot flashes, leg cramps are generally mild; vaginal bleeding is occasional.
  • Raloxifene has antiestrogen effects on breast and uterine tissue but estrogenic effects on bone, and it is used to prevent osteoporosis.
  • It is not used to treat breast cancer, menopausal symptoms or endometriosis, or for contraception.

Key Takeaway

  • Raloxifene has antiestrogen effects on breast and uterine tissue but estrogenic effects on bone, and it is used to prevent osteoporosis
  • Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator with estrogen agonist action on bone and liver. It is associated with increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and is contraindicated in adults with a history of venous thromboembolism

choices.text: It is formed from the dorsal rami of S2-4 spinal nerves
It courses between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles
When injecting local anesthetic at the time of nerve block, the ischial spine serves an identifiable landmark
It may be at risk of stretch injury during downward displacement of the pelvic floor during childbirth

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the structure shown below (with a yellow arrow), except:
questions.solution:
• The pudendal nervecarries motor and sensory axons arising from the ventral (& not dorsal) rami of the sacral spinal nerves S2-S4.
  • It courses between the piriformis and coccygeus muscles and exits through the greater sciatic foramen at a location posterior to the sacrospinous ligament and just medial to the ischial spine.
  • Thus, when injecting local anesthetic for a pudendal nerve block, the ischial spine serves an identifiable landmark.
  • In general, the pudendal nerve is relatively fixed as it courses behind the sacrospinous ligament and within the pudendal canal. Accordingly, it may be at risk of stretch injury during downward displacement of the pelvic floor during childbirth.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Parasympathetic innervation to the pelvic organs derives rom spinal levels S2 through S4
  • For the cervix and upper part of the birth canal, sensory nerves pass through the pelvic splanchnic nerves to the second, third, and fourth sacral nerves.
  • Last, those from the lower portion of the birth canal pass primarily through the pudendal nerve. Anesthetic blocks used during delivery target these levels of innervation

questions.text: The following intrauterine device is used for contraception for up to 5 years. Which of the following medication does this device release?
questions.solution:
• The intrauterine device that is effective for 5 years is Mirena IUCD releasing levonorgestrel.
  • IUCD results in 1000 fold higher local progestin levels than systemic levels.
  • They act predominantly by inhibiting gamete function and survival via local changes in cervical mucous.
  • Implants
  • These are drug delivery systems implanted under the skin, from which the steroid is released slowly over a period of 1-5 years.
  • They consist of either-
  • (a) Biodegradable polymeric matrices-do not need to be removed on expiry.
  • (b) Non-biodegradable rubber membranes-have to be removed on expiry.
  • NORPLANT: A set of 6 capsules each containing 36 mg levonorgestrel (total 216 mg) for subcutaneous implantation is available in some countries. It works for up to 5 years.
  • A progestin impregnated intrauterine insert (PROGESTASERT) has been introduced in some countries.
  • It contains 52 mg of levonorgestrel which primarily acts locally on endometrium. The device remains effective for 5 years, but efficacy is rated lower.

Key takeaway

  • The intrauterine device that is effective for 5 years is Mirena IUCD releasing levonorgestrel.

questions.text: Main lymphatic drainage of ovaries goes to which group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
• The main lymphatic drainage from ovaries goes to para-aortic lymph nodes, depicted by A.
  • B, C & D are internal iliac, external iliac & superficial inguinal LN respectively.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Lymphatic drainage from ovaries:-

questions.text: While performing an autopsy on a burn victim, the following cutaneous findings were noted. What is the term used to describe these burns?
questions.solution:
• Filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg's flower or feathering is a finding in burns due to lightning.
  • The fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two.
  • It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree.

Incorrect Options-

Option A- Crocodile burns- Caused by high tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions.

Option B: When the skin is in firm contact with an electrical conductor, splitting of the layers of the epidermis or those of the epidermal-dermal junction occurs. This may in turn produce a raised blister known as a Joule burn.

Option C-Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and conductor.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg's flower or feathering is a finding in burns due to lightning.

questions.text: A 24 year old G1P0 woman presents to Obstetric OPD at 7 weeks of amenorrhoea with a positive UPT. The gynaecologist does a gentle bimanual examination (as shown below), and her abdominal & vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. Which clinical sign of pregnancy is being elicited here?
questions.solution:
• Hegar sign is a non-specific indication of pregnancy characterized by the compressibility & softening of the cervical isthmus.
  • It is elicited by doing a gentle bimanual examination, wherein the abdominal & vaginal fingers seem to appose just below the body of the uterus.
  • It can be demonstrated between 6 to 10 weeks of pregnancy, a little earlier in multiparae.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Tags:

  • Topic: Diagnosis of pregnancy
  • PYQ INICET NEET

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in casualty when an MLC case is brought by the police with the following appearance. She was declared brought dead. What would you mark as the likely cause of death before sending the patient for postmortem?
questions.solution:
• Drowning is a form of asphyxia resulting from aspiration of fluid into air passages caused by submersion of water or other fluids.
  • External findings -
    • Fine, white tenacious copious froth that doesn't rapidly collapse and reappear after being wiped out.
      • It is the most important finding suggestive of Antemortem drowning.
    • Cutis anserina -goose skin
    • Cadaveric spasm- It is the surest sign of antemortem drowning.
    • Washer woman hands- Skin of the limbs become sodden and wrinkled.

Incorrect Options -

Option B- Hanging-It is a form of asphyxia caused by suspension of body by ligature that encircles the neck.

  • Complete hanging: Body is completely
  • Incomplete hanging: Part of the body is in contact with the ground or other surface.

Option C-Strangulation -It is the constriction of neck by means rather than suspending the body ,it can be ligature strangulation or by hands-manual strangulation/throttling.

Option D-Traumatic asphyxia -Mechanical fixation of chest by unyielding substance /object leading to respiratory failure.

Intense cyanosis and congestion above the level of compression is a characteristic feature.

Fig. Masque ecchymotique

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Drowning is a form of asphyxia resulting from aspiration of fluid into air passages caused by submersion of water or other fluids.

questions.text: Identify this recently introduced device for assisted vaginal birth:
questions.solution:
Other options:

a. Kiwi Omnicup: A vacuum extraction device designed for assisted vaginal delivery. It features a soft, flexible cup that creates suction to help deliver the fetus while minimizing scalp trauma. The Omnicup can be used in various fetal positions and is particularly effective in cases where a cephalic presentation is maintained.

c. Fetal Pillow: A soft, inflatable device used to support the fetal head during delivery, particularly in cases of fetal distress. It provides a cushion that can help with positioning and alignment of the fetal head in the birth canal, potentially improving outcomes during labor.

d. C-snorkel: The C-Snorkel is a disposable tube with ventilation ports, intended to release the vacuum between the fetal head andvaginal wall. There are very little data on its use.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Odon device recently introduced device for assisted vaginal birth

  • Topic: Recent advances in operative obstetrics

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a deliriant toxin.
questions.solution:
Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the cultivated varieties of coca.

  • Characteristic PM findings in chronic cocaine poisoning:
    • Black tongue and teeth
    • Magnan symptoms/cocaine bugs -tactile hallucinations, also known as formication.
    • Nasal and palate perforation
    • Gangrene of nose tip, ear pinna etc

Incorrect Options -

Option B and C- Datura and hyoscine - Presents as dry mouth, delirium, dry hot skin, dilated pupils, drowsiness and death due to respiratory failure.

It is known as stupefying agent.

Option D - Aconite -Also known as meetha zeher, characteristically causes Tingling followed by numbness of mouth and throat

It also causes Hippus - Alternate contraction and dilatation of pupil.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Triad of cocaine abuse involves nasal/palatal perforation, black tongue and gangrene of peripheries.

questions.text: Identify the incision marked by yellow arrow in the following image:
questions.solution:
The Pfannenstiel incision is a transverse skin incision, two finger-breadths above the symphysis pubis, which is extended in the direction of the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and ends 2-3 cm medial to ASIS on both sides.

Usage: Frequently used for C-sections as it offers a strong closure and lower incidence of hernia formation.


Here's a brief definition for each of the incisions:

b. Joel-Cohen Incision

  • Definition: A straight transverse incision made slightly higher than the Pfannenstiel incision, about 3 cm above the pubic symphysis. It involves blunt dissection of the rectus muscles and less tissue trauma.
  • Usage: Known for faster healing and reduced blood loss, often preferred in elective cesarean deliveries.

c. Maylard Incision

  • Definition: A higher transverse incision, cutting through the rectus abdominis muscles, often located above the usual Pfannenstiel incision. It requires cutting the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Usage: Used when greater access to the pelvis is required, such as in gynecological cancer surgeries.

d. Kerr's Incision

  • Definition: A low transverse uterine incision, commonly used during cesarean sections. It involves a horizontal cut on the lower uterine segment.
  • Usage: This incision reduces the risk of uterine rupture in future pregnancies, making it the most preferred method for cesarean sections.

KEY TAKEAWAY -


Topic: Abdominal incisions in gynaecology

  • PYQ: NEET

questions.text: The image given below is a type of _____.
questions.solution:
• A contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.
  • A pure bruise lies beneath an intact epidermis.
  • Bruises are caused by damage to veins, venules, and small arteries.
  • The usual bruise from a blunt impact is situated in the subcutaneous tissues, often in the fat layer. (Because of the greater volume of soft subcutaneous tissue in fat people, they tend to bruise more easily than thin ones).

Incorrect Options-

Option B- Abrasion- Also known as gravel rash; It is the destruction of skin , which usually involves superficial layers of epidermis only.

Option C-Laceration-It is the tears or split of skin and underlying tissue produced by application of blunt force to the broad area of the body, which stretches the tissue beyond the limits of their elasticity.

Option D-Stab wound -When force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow pointed object such as knife, sword etc.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- contusion is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneous and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force.

questions.text: A 32 year old G5P1L0A3D1 woman visited an obstetrician at 18 weeks of gestation. She was asked to get an anomaly scan done, which showed the following sonographic sign. The liquor was scanty too. Which of the below mentioned syndromes is the prime cause of concern for the woman?
questions.solution:
The term "lying down adrenal sign" has been ascribed to the elongated appearance of the adrenal, not normally molded by the adjacent kidney, seen in Potter's syndrome.

Potter's Syndrome is bilateral renal agenesis exemplified by pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities, and typical facies. It is frequently associated with oligohydramnios.

a. Contradi syndrome:

This is not a commonly recognized syndrome associated with oligohydramnios or specific sonographic signs in pregnancy.

b. Moebius syndrome:

Moebius syndrome primarily affects cranial nerves and results in facial paralysis and other abnormalities, but it is not specifically linked to oligohydramnios or the described findings.

d. Denys-Drash syndrome:

This syndrome is associated with Wilms tumor and genital abnormalities, as well as renal dysplasia, but it is not primarily characterized by oligohydramnios or the specific sonographic findings typical of Potter's syndrome.

In summary, Potter's syndrome is the prime concern for the woman, given the scanty liquor and the context provided.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • If renal agenesis is bilateral, no urine is produced, and the resulting anhydramnios leads to pulmonary hypoplasia, limb contractures, and distinctive facies. When this combination results from renal agenesis, it is called Potter syndrome,
  • When these abnormalities result from severely decreased amnionic fluid volume from another etiology, such as bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney or autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, it is called Potter sequence.

Tags:

  • Topic: Oligohydramnios

questions.text: A 43-year-old man working in the mining industry presents with painful paraesthesias of his hands and feet. Examination of the limbs reveals the following findings. Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given images (raindrop pigmentation and Mees lines) along with the clinical features are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Chelation therapy for subacute or chronic severe arsenic toxicity is succimer (DMSA).

TIPS AND TRICK -ARSENIC

  • A-Abortion

Aldrich mees lines

  • R-Red velvety mucosa

Raindrop pigmentation

Reinsch test/marsh test

  • S-Subendocardial hemorrhage
  • E-Excessive pigmentation of palm and soles
  • N-Neuropathy
  • I- Iron oxide used in gastric lavage
  • C- Mimics Cholera

The other 3 options - A ,C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Chelation therapy for subacute or chronic severe arsenic toxicity is succimer (DMSA).

For acute arsenic toxicity, the following can be used:

  • BAL (British anti-Lewisite)
  • DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid)
  • DMPS (Dimercaptopropane-1-sulfonate)

BAL tends to remain the initial chelating drug for severe, acute arsenic toxicity.

questions.text: Identify this placental anomaly:
questions.solution:
PLACENTA SUCCENTURIATA: One (usual) or more small lobes of placenta, size of a cotyledon, may be placed at varying distances from the main placental margin. A leash of vessels connecting the main to the small lobe traverse through the membranes. The accessory lobe is developed from the activated villi on the chorionic laeve.


CIRCUMVALLATE PLACENTA: The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete. The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between.


PLACENTA MEMBRANACEA: The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta.


KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Battledore placenta in which the cord anchors at the placental margin.
  • In monochorionic twins, marginal insertion may be associated with weight discordance

  • PYQ: INICET July 2020 November 2022, FMGE June 2020
  • Topic: Placental anomalies

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image?

  • Depressed fracture is also known as signature fracture.
  • Caused by an object with large amount of kinetic energy and small striking surface area.
  • Pattern of fracture often resembles the weapon or agent causing it .

Incorrect Options -

Option A- Ring fracture -Seen when someone falls from height and lands on ground.

It is seen around foramen magnum.

Option C- Fissured fracture -Also known as linear fracture, it is the most common type of skull fracture. Caused by blow with a broad striking surface.

Option D- Comminuted fracture -Also known a spider web fracture.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Depressed fracture is also known as signature fracture.

Caused by an object with large amount of kinetic energy and small striking surface area.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient is being evaluated for longstanding anemia. On clinical examination, you notice the given finding. Which of the following metal poisoning is associated with this characteristic finding?
questions.solution:
The image is showing characteristic Burtonian lines, which are associated with lead poisoning.

These are bluish -grey lead lines that occur with chronic exposure to lead poisoning.

  • Lead inhibits ALA Dehydratase and ferrochelatase resulting in microcytic hypochromic anemia.
  • TIPS AND TRICK for lead poisoning -
  • A- Anemia
  • B-Basophilic stippling
  • C- Colic and constipation "Lead leads to lead lines":
  • D- Drops -wrist drop
  • E- Encephalopathy
  • F-Facial pallor (earliest feature)

Incorrect Options-

Option A- Thallium -Alopecia, skin rash and painful peripheral neuropathy.

Characteristic of thallium poisoning - Loss of outer 2/3 of eyebrows.

Option B - Arsenic poisoning -Presents with

  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Aldrich mees lines and garlic odour of breath, alopecia etc.

Option D- Berylliosis- It doesn’t present with Burtonian lines.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Burtonian lines are associated with lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 24 year old primigravida reports to LR at 37 weeks of gestation in early labour. USG shows a single live intrauterine fetus of 36 weeks 5 days gestation FHR 150 bpm, AFI 3 cm, EFW 2.6 kg. Identify the pattern of CTG shown below:
questions.solution:
• The image shows variable decelerations.
  • Variable decelerations are variable in onset, duration and depth.
  • They may occur with contractions or between contractions.
  • Typically, they have an abrupt onset and rapid recovery.
  • Oligohydramnios is associated with more frequent variable decelerations as the amniotic fluid has a protective role on the fetal umbilical cord, and studies have suggested that the use of amnioinfusion may improve the FHR pattern.

Optionwise explanation:

Option a) Early Deceleration

  • The FHR decline mirrors the contraction in timing, creating a "mirror image" where the nadir (lowest point) of the FHR occurs at the peak of the contraction.
  • Early decelerations are usually benign and do not indicate fetal distress. They are common in late labor as the fetal head descends into the pelvis.

Option b) Late Deceleration

  • Definition: Late decelerations are gradual decreases in FHR that begin after the peak of a uterine contraction and return to baseline after the contraction ends.
  • Cause: They are caused by uteroplacental insufficiency, which results in decreased oxygenation to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The deceleration starts after the contraction has begun, and the lowest point of FHR occurs after the peak of the contraction.
  • Clinical Significance: Late decelerations can be a sign of fetal hypoxia and distress, especially when repetitive and associated with minimal variability or bradycardia. They may require intervention, such as changing maternal position, oxygen administration, or even urgent delivery.

Option d) Sinusoidal Pattern

  • Definition: A sinusoidal pattern is a smooth, wave-like oscillation of the FHR with regular amplitude and frequency, without normal short-term variability.
  • Cause: It is associated with severe fetal anemia, fetal hypoxia, or other serious fetal conditions (e.g., Rh isoimmunization, fetal-maternal hemorrhage).
  • Pattern: The pattern has a fixed, undulating waveform that lasts for at least 20 minutes.
  • Clinical Significance: A true sinusoidal pattern is considered an ominous sign of severe fetal distress or anemia and requires immediate evaluation and usually prompt delivery.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Variable Deceleration

  • Definition: Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in FHR that vary in timing, duration, and shape, often resembling "V", "U", or "W" patterns.
  • Cause: They are usually caused by umbilical cord compression, which leads to a brief reduction in blood flow to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The onset and recovery of variable decelerations are quick and may or may not be associated with contractions.
  • Clinical Significance: Occasional variable decelerations are common and may not be concerning if the variability remains normal. However, recurrent or severe variable decelerations, especially with slow recovery or reduced variability, may indicate fetal compromise and require intervention.

Tags:

  • Topic: Variable deceleration

questions.text: Identify this method used in the delivery of aftercoming head of breech:
questions.solution:
Option b Pinard's method is used to deliver extended legs in breech

Option c Piper's forceps is used to deliver aftercoming head of breech

Option d Lovset's maneuver is used to deliver extended arms in breech.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Burns-Marshall method

  • The baby is allowed to hang by its own weight.
  • The assistant is asked to give suprapubic pressure with the flat of hand in a downward and backward direction, the pressure is to be exerted more toward the sinciput. The aim is to promote flexion of the head so that favorable diameter is presented to the pelvic cavity.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby is grasped by the ankles with a finger in between the two. Maintaining a steady traction and forming a wide arc of a circle, the trunk is swung in upward and forward direction (as shown in the figure).
  • Meanwhile, with the left hand to guard the perineum, slipping the perineum off successively the face and brow.
  • When the mouth is cleared off the vulva, there should be no hurry. Mucus of the mouth and pharynx is cleared by mucus sucker.
  • The trunk is depressed to deliver rest of the head.

Tags:

  • PYQ INICET November, 2020
  • Topic: Breech delivery

questions.text: A 45-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?

The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance of Boric acid poisoning.

Option B- Hydrochloric acid- Also known as muriatic acid ,it is a less corrosive acid hence perforation of stomach, corrosion of skin are rare .

Deposition in cartilage -ochronosis

Causes Carboluria- dark green colored urine
