questions.text: A 30 year old G2POA1 woman comes to Labour Room with complaints of lower abdominal pain since 8 hours, leaking per vaginum since 4hours. On per vaginal examination she has a cervical dilatation of 6 cm, cervical length of 1 cm, ruptured membranes with clear liquor, station of vertex at 0 and regular uterine contractions. In a duration of 3 hours, she became fully dilated and then in another 2 hours, head was seen crowning at the perineum. Which of the following manoeuvres is being performed (as shown in the figure) for the delivery of head in these circumstances?
questions.solution:
Modified Ritgen Maneuver is correct as it is used in controlled delivery of head.

Option b Prague maneuver is used for Occipitoposterior position.

Option c Lovset maneuver is for delivery of extended arms in breech.

Option d MSV maneuver is to deliver aftercoming head of breech.

  • When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of 5 cm or more, a gloved hand may be used to support the perineum. The other hand is used to guide and control the fetal head to deliver the smallest head diameter through the introitus and to avoid expulsive delivery.
  • Slow delivery of the head may decrease lacerations. Overall, bracing the perineum lowers rates of anal sphincter injury compared with a "hands off" approach to delivery.
  • Alternatively, if expulsive efforts are inadequate or expeditious delivery is needed, the modified Ritgen maneuver may be employed or an episiotomy cut.
  • With the modified maneuver, gloved fingers beneath a draped towel exert forward pressure on the fetal chin through the perineum just in front of the coccyx (as shown in the figure).

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

MSV maneuver


Loveset Maneuver


Prague maneuver


Topic: Delivery of fetus

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was accidentally shot by a friend while they were trying to experiment with how to use a gun. His gunshot wound is shown in the image below. Which of the following features are not seen in this wound?
questions.solution:
In the given image we see that there is blackening, tattooing as well as an abrasion collar but wound edge eversion is not seen.

The features seen in the image indicate that this was a close shot, i.e., the distance between the victim and the firing is 5-8cm. The victim is within the range of the flame, hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition will be seen. Singeing, burning, blackening and tattooing will be present.

In a firm contact shot, the imprint of the muzzle of the gun is seen on the skin around the wound. Wound edge eversion is also seen. The victim is within the range of flame, hence singeing of the hair will be present. Tattooing begins only when the muzzle-to-target distance is >1cm, like in a loose contact shot.

When the distance between the victim and the firing is >50 cm, it is a distant shot. The victim lies outside the range of flame and powder deposition. Hence, features related to flame, smoke, and powder deposition are absent. Burning, blackening, and tattooing are absent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and heavy menstrual bleeding. Imaging reveals a large ovarian mass. Histological examination shows small round follicles and Call-Exner bodies (as shown in the image). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary that are often hormonally active, leading to symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding.

OPTION A: Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors lined by epithelium resembling the fallopian tube. These tumors are typically filled with a thin, watery fluid and do not contain Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles, which are characteristic of granulosa cell tumors.

OPTION B: Mucinous cystadenomas are also benign ovarian tumors but are lined by mucus-producing epithelium. These tumors are generally multilocular and filled with a thick, mucinous fluid. Like serous cystadenomas, they do not exhibit Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles.

OPTION D: Clear cell carcinoma is a malignant epithelial ovarian tumor known for its aggressive behaviour. It is characterized by the presence of clear cells and hobnail cells. However, it does not typically show Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles, which are specific to granulosa cell tumors.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The presence of these Call Exner bodies, along with small round follicles, is strongly indicative of a granulosa cell tumor.

HISTOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF OVARIAN TUMORS


Topic: Histology of Ovarian Tumors

questions.text: Hypopyon corneal ulcer is most commonly caused by which of the following organisms:
questions.solution:
Hypopyon Corneal Ulcer:

Etiopathogenesis

  • Causative Organisms:
    • Pneumococcus: Classic "ulcus serpens."
    • Corneal ulcer WITH hypopyon: Staphylococci, Streptococci, Gonococci, Moraxella, Pseudomonas.
    • Source: Chronic dacryocystitis (especially for pneumococcal ulcers).
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Virulence of organisms.
    • Weakened host resistance (e.g., old age, alcoholism).
  • Mechanism:
    • Bacterial toxins cause iritis → leukocytes accumulate in the anterior chamber → sterile hypopyon.
    • Resolves as the ulcer heals.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms: Similar to bacterial ulcers but early stages of ulcus serpens show minimal pain.
  • Signs (Ulcus Serpens):
    • Greyish-white/yellow disc-shaped central ulcer.
    • Spreads in a serpiginous pattern with uneven edges.
    • Associated violent iridocyclitis and hypopyon.
    • Rapid progression → secondary glaucoma and risk of perforation.

Management

  • General treatment for bacterial corneal ulcers.
  • Special considerations:
    • Treat secondary glaucoma (e.g., timolol maleate 0.5%, acetazolamide).
    • Address infection source (e.g., dacryocystectomy for chronic dacryocystitis).

Complications

  1. Toxic Iridocyclitis: Toxin absorption into the anterior chamber.
  2. Secondary Glaucoma: Inflammatory exudates block the angle.
  3. Descemetocele: Herniation of Descemet’s membrane → impending perforation.
  4. Perforation: Sudden rupture from strain → sequelae:
    • Iris prolapse, lens dislocation, anterior capsular cataract, corneal fistula.
    • Severe outcomes: Uveitis, endophthalmitis, panophthalmitis, intraocular hemorrhage.
  5. Corneal Scarring: Permanent vision impairment ranging from nebula to anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: Identify the following procedure performed for reduction in the growth of uterine leiomyomas:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) uses high-frequency electrical energy to generate heat, which is applied to the fibroid tissue. The heat causes the fibroid cells to shrink and die.

Technique: The procedure is often performed laparoscopically or via a transvaginal approach. A specialized needle-like probe is inserted into the fibroid under ultrasound or MRI guidance. The probe delivers the radiofrequency energy, targeting the fibroid.


OPTION B: MRgFUS uses high-intensity focused ultrasound waves to generate heat and ablate (destroy) the fibroid tissue. The procedure is guided by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which allows precise targeting and monitoring of the treatment area.

Technique: The patient lies inside an MRI scanner, and the focused ultrasound energy is delivered through the skin, targeting the fibroid tissue without the need for any incisions.


OPTION C: Uterine Artery Embolization (UAE) is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat symptomatic uterine fibroids by cutting off their blood supply, leading to their shrinkage and symptom relief. UAE involves injecting small particles (embolic agents) into the arteries supplying the fibroids. These particles block the blood flow to the fibroids, causing them to shrink over time due to lack of oxygen and nutrients.


OPTION D: HIFU (High Intensity Focussed Ultrasound) uses high-intensity focused ultrasound waves to generate localized heat in the fibroid tissue, causing thermal ablation (destruction) of the fibroid cells without affecting surrounding tissues.


KEY TAKEAWAY:

UAE works by blocking the blood supply to fibroids, causing them to shrink and lose their "feast" on blood flow.

Topic: Management of Fibroid (Recent advances)

Reference: www.researchgate.com

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician due to a noticeable white reflex in her left eye, which was first observed by her parents during family photos taken with a flash. Upon examination, the right eye appears normal, but the left eye shows a prominent leukocoria. The child has no significant past medical history, and there is no similar family history. A detailed fundus examination reveals a mass in the retina with a cauliflower-like appearance and areas of calcification. To further evaluate, an ultrasound of the eye is performed, confirming the presence of intraocular calcification. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the chromosome 13.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma:

Definition

  • Retinoblastoma is a proliferation of abnormal neural cells in the retina.
  • Previously known as "glioma" retinae, but it's now termed retinoblastoma due to rare neuroglial growths in the retina.

Aetiology

  • Affects infants and young children, often congenital but can remain undetected until later childhood.
  • The disease is rare; approximately 25% of cases affect the fellow eye.
  • 10% of cases have a family history, with a dominant inheritance pattern.
  • Associated with mutations in the RB1 gene on chromosome 13, leading to unchecked retinal cell division.

Pathology

  • The tumour consists of small round cells resembling retinal cells.
  • Microscopic features include necrosis, rosette formations (resembling rods and cones).
  • It can grow outward (glioma exophytum) or inward (glioma endophytum), causing different ophthalmoscopic appearances.
  • Retinoblastoma is usually multiple, often seen as a cauliflower-like mass with calcifications.

Clinical Course

  • Common symptoms: Leukocoria (white reflex), squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.
  • Disease progression includes:
    1. Quiescent stage (6 months to 1 year).
    2. Glaucomatous stage (enlarged globe, proptosis).
    3. Extraocular extension.
    4. Metastasis (rarely to organs other than the brain, optic nerve, and bones).
  • Ophthalmoscopic findings: Cauliflower-like masses, neovascularization, vitreous seedings, or retinal detachment.

Classification

  • Reese-Ellsworth Classification (for intraocular retinoblastoma):
    • Group I: Solitary tumour < 4 DD, at or behind the equator.
    • Group V: Massive tumours, vitreous seeding (worst prognosis).
  • International Classification (since 1990):
    • Based on tumor size, location, and extent of spread.
    • Prognosis for disease-free survival >90% for intraocular cases, <10% for extraocular extension.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Conditions like inflammatory deposits, Toxocara infestation, Norrie disease, and retrolental fibroplasia can mimic retinoblastoma.
  • Pseudoglioma conditions are distinguished by eye pressure (raised in retinoblastoma) and ophthalmoscopic findings.

Diagnosis

  • Calcification is seen in 75% of cases (detected via X-rays, CT scan).
  • Ultrasound: Characteristic cauliflower-like mass, retinal detachment, or vitreous seedings.
  • Biochemical tests: Elevated lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) in aqueous humor.

Treatment

  • Small tumours: Local therapies such as cryotherapy, photocoagulation, brachytherapy.
  • Chemoreduction: Combination chemotherapy (vincristine, carboplatin, etoposide) to shrink the tumour before further therapy.
  • Large tumours: Chemotherapy followed by local management or enucleation if necessary.
  • Enucleation: Performed if the tumour involves the optic nerve or cannot be treated locally.
  • Radiation therapy used with caution, particularly in young children, due to the risk of secondary malignancies.

Prognosis

  • Intraocular retinoblastoma: 5-year disease-free survival >90%.
  • Extraocular extension: 5-year disease-free survival <10%.
  • Post-treatment care: Lifelong monitoring for recurrence, especially for siblings and descendants due to familial risk.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Bonney's clamp is used in myomectomy, It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily thereby minimising the blood loss during operation.

OPTION A: The Doyen Myoma Screw is a specialized instrument that features a screw-like design. This allows it to grip and hold myomas securely, making them easier to remove during myomectomy.


OPTION B: Shirodkar's uterus holding forceps is Used to extract tissue, tumors, or polyps from the uterus by elevating the vaginal wall. The clamps at the end of the ring handles feature serrated jaws to firmly grasp the tissue to be removed. The clamps are curved to the side to optimize visualization during procedures.


OPTION C: Bonney's clamp is used in myomectomy, It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily thereby minimising the blood loss during operation.

OPTION D: Green-Armytage forceps are used to grasp and clamp tissue in the uterus. the forceps has wide blades with horizontal serrations. the forceps are used for edges of the transverse incision in the lower segment.


KEY TAKEAWAY: Bonney's clamp is used in myomectomy, It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily thereby minimising the blood loss during operation.

William Francis Victor Bonney was a prominent British gynaecological surgeon. His wife Annie suffered from very heavy periods which in turn resulted in severe anaemia and was corrected by a hysterectomy, thus preventing her having children. This setback led to Bonney's lifelong advocacy for the more conservative surgery of myomectomy over the more radical hysterectomy.

Tags:

  • Topic: Myomectomy
  • PYQ NEET INICET

Reference: www.ncbi.com

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and mild fever. She has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). On examination, tenderness is noted in the right upper quadrant. LFTs are normal. The following laparoscopic image is seen. What is the most plausible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The differential diagnosis for Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome primarily includes conditions that present with right upper quadrant pain and systemic symptoms like fever. Distinguishing between these conditions requires a combination of clinical history, physical examination, laboratory tests, and imaging studies.


OPTION A: Liver enzymes are normal. So acute hepatitis can be ruled out.

OPTION B: Acute cholecystitis would not have such adhesions as seen in the laparoscopic image.

OPTION C: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome is a perihepatitis associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It is characterized by the presence of "violin-string" adhesions between the liver capsule and the abdominal wall, as seen in the image. The condition typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, which may be mistaken for gallbladder or liver pathology.

OPTION D: Acute appendicitis will present with right iliac fossa pain & not RUQ pain.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome often presents with right upper quadrant pain that closely resembles gallbladder disease, leading many to initially suspect conditions like cholecystitis.
  • However, this pain is actually caused by adhesions between the liver and the abdominal wall, often called "violin-string" adhesions.
  • These adhesions are a unique and unexpected complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), making this condition an intriguing crossover between gynecology and hepatology!

Tags:

  • Topic: Complications of PID
  • PYQ FMGE Jan 2022

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of excessive tearing, photophobia, and large eyes noticed since infancy. Examination reveals bilateral corneal edema and a horizontal corneal diameter 14 mm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B) Congenital glaucoma: This is the correct answer.

  • Buphthalmos (enlarged eye) is a hallmark of congenital glaucoma due to elevated intraocular pressure in infancy.
  • The classic triad of congenital glaucoma includes tearing (epiphora), photophobia, and blepharospasm.
  • The increased corneal diameter (>12 mm in infants), corneal edema, and an increased cup-to-disc ratio further support the diagnosis
  • Option A) Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome: This is a developmental anomaly characterized by anterior segment dysgenesis, often with features such as corectopia, iris hypoplasia, and posterior embryotoxon.
  • It does not typically cause buphthalmos or elevated intraocular pressure from birth.
  • Option C) Peters anomaly: This refers to central corneal opacity due to abnormal development of the anterior segment, but it does not cause buphthalmos or elevated intraocular pressure.
  • Option D) Sclerocornea: This is a condition where the cornea becomes opaque and blends with the sclera, but it does not involve elevated intraocular pressure or buphthalmos.

Congenital glaucoma :

  • is typically diagnosed in the first few years of life and results from improper development of the anterior chamber angle, leading to impaired aqueous outflow and elevated intraocular pressure.
  • This increased pressure causes eye enlargement (buphthalmos) due to the elasticity of the infantile sclera.
  • Treatment is primarily surgical, with procedures like goniotomy or trabeculotomy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for abnormal uterine bleeding has an endometrial thickness of 12 mm on ultrasound. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Performing a hysteroscopy is the most appropriate next step because it allows direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. This procedure is useful for diagnosing endometrial pathology such as polyps, fibroids, or endometrial hyperplasia, which can be associated with increased endometrial thickness. It also allows for potential biopsy of abnormal tissue for histological examination, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

OPTION A: Hormonal therapy might be considered if there is a diagnosis of hormonal imbalance or if symptoms are related to hormonal issues. However, it does not address the need to evaluate the cause of the abnormal endometrial thickness. Without determining the underlying cause, starting hormonal therapy could be empirical and might not resolve the underlying issue.

OPTION C: Repeating the ultrasound in 6 months might delay the diagnosis and management of potential endometrial pathology. While follow-up imaging might be necessary in some cases, the current abnormal endometrial thickness warrants further investigation rather than postponing evaluation.

OPTION D: While MRI provides detailed imaging and can be useful for assessing the extent and characteristics of endometrial pathology, it is not the first-line investigation for evaluating abnormal endometrial thickness. Hysteroscopy is preferred for direct evaluation and biopsy, which are essential for diagnosis. MRI may be considered later if additional detailed imaging is required.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

For premenopausal women, an endometrial thickness (ET) of 12 mm is generally considered above the normal range and warrants further evaluation. The specific cut-off values can vary based on guidelines and clinical practice, but typically:


For postmenopausal women, an endometrial thickness (ET) of 4 mm or greater generally prompts further evaluation due to the increased risk of endometrial pathology, including endometrial cancer.

Tags:

  • Topic: Imaging in AUB
  • PYQ- NEET, INICET

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with a sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen:

Given this presentation, which of the following is most likely not a complication of the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• D) Retinal detachment: Correct. Retinal detachment is not a typical complication of CRVO. The most common complications involve neovascularization, macular edema, and hemorrhages.
  • A) Neovascular glaucoma: This is a known complication of ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) due to the development of neovascularization of the iris, which can lead to secondary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • B) Vitreous hemorrhage: Vitreous hemorrhage can occur as a result of retinal neovascularization, which is a common complication in ischemic CRVO.
  • C) Macular edema: Macular edema is the most common cause of vision loss in CRVO. It results from fluid leakage due to retinal vein blockage and is seen in both ischemic and non-ischemic CRVO.

CRVO:

  • often divided into ischemic and non-ischemic types.
  • Ischemic CRVO has a higher risk of severe complications such as neovascular glaucoma and retinal neovascularization, while non-ischemic CRVO is typically less severe but can still result in significant vision loss due to macular edema.

Tags: CRVO, retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 32 year old P3L3 woman with previous 2 LSCS presents with HMB since past 6 months. On clinical examination, her uterus is ~12 weeks size, boggy, mildly tender. USG shows the following appearance. What could be the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:

choices.text: Shifting fluid with no retinal breaks

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of flashes and floaters in her right eye, followed by the sensation of a curtain-like shadow descending over her visual field. She denies pain. Her past medical history includes high myopia and cataract surgery 5 years ago. On fundoscopic examination, below findings are noted. Fluorescein angiography shows no abnormal vascular leakage.

Which of the following findings would exclude the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above shown fundus is of rhegmatogenous RD with horseshoe tear.

  • Option B) Shifting fluid with no retinal breaks: Correct. This finding is characteristic of exudative retinal detachment, not rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Exudative detachments occur due to fluid accumulation under the retina from inflammatory, vascular, or neoplastic processes and do not involve retinal tears or breaks.
  • Option A) Presence of retinal neovascularization: Retinal neovascularization can occur secondary to various retinal conditions such as proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which may result in tractional detachment, but its presence does not exclude rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, especially if tears are present.
  • Option C) History of high myopia: High myopia is a significant risk factor for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment due to the increased likelihood of peripheral retinal degeneration and retinal tears.
  • Option D) Retinal tears at the periphery: Peripheral retinal tears are a hallmark of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which occurs when vitreous fluid enters through these breaks, leading to retinal separation.

Overview:

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment and is characterized by a retinal break that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. The typical symptoms include photopsia (flashes), floaters, and a curtain-like shadow over the visual field. It can be differentiated from other types of retinal detachment as follows:

  • Tractional retinal detachment: Caused by pulling forces on the retina due to fibrovascular proliferation, commonly seen in diabetic retinopathy or retinopathy of prematurity. It lacks retinal breaks but can cause detachment due to traction forces.
  • Exudative (serous) retinal detachment: Characterized by subretinal fluid without retinal breaks. It is caused by inflammation, neoplasms, or vascular disorders, and fluid shifts with head positioning.

questions.text: Identify this hallmark renal lesion seen in cases of preeclampsia:
questions.solution:
Glomerular endotheliosis is the characteristic renal lesion of preeclampsia. It is marked by swelling and damage to the endothelial cells of the glomeruli, leading to proteinuria. This is the hallmark lesion of preeclampsia.


Optionwise explanation:

a) Membranous nephropathy

  • This is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome, characterized by thickened glomerular basement membranes. It is not typically associated with preeclampsia.

b) Membranoproliferative nephropathy

  • This condition involves both membrane thickening and cell proliferation in the glomeruli. It is not a hallmark lesion of preeclampsia.

d) Nephrosclerosis

  • Nephrosclerosis refers to hardening of the small blood vessels in the kidneys, typically due to chronic hypertension. While hypertension is involved in preeclampsia, nephrosclerosis is not the hallmark lesion.

Key TAKEAWAY -In preeclampsia, the changes are conspicuous in the glomerulus which becomes enlarged (glomerular endotheliosis).

  • Endothelial cells swell up and fibrin-like deposits occur in the basement membrane. The lumen may be occluded. Interstitial cells in between the capillaries proliferate.
  • There is associated spasm of the afferent glomerular arterioles. Patchy areas of damage of the tubular epithelium due to anoxia are evident.

Topic: Pathophysiology of preeclampsia

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a painful red eye, photophobia, and reduced vision in her right eye. She has a history of recurrent cold sores and reports that she recently experienced another outbreak. Slit-lamp examination with Fluorescein staining reveals below findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen for her condition?
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) keratitis is the most common form of viral keratitis and can present as dendritic ulcers on the cornea, which are characteristic for HSV epithelial keratitis.

  • The treatment regimen typically involves Acyclovir in both oral and topical forms to inhibit viral replication. For active HSV epithelial keratitis, the recommended dose of Acyclovir is:
    • Acyclovir 400 mg orally, five times a day, for 7-21 days, followed by maintenance dose of 400mg two times a day with monitoring of LFT and RFT..
    • Acyclovir 3% ointment, applied five times a day, for 7-10 days.

This combined approach helps ensure effective viral suppression both systemically and locally on the eye.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B. Acyclovir 400 mg oral three times a day + Acyclovir 5% eye ointment three times a day: This dosage regimen is insufficient for treating active HSV keratitis and might not provide adequate viral suppression.
  • Option C. Acyclovir 800 mg oral twice a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment twice a day: The oral dose is typically higher for other indications like herpes zoster, not for HSV keratitis. Topical application twice a day is insufficient.
  • Option D. Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment three times a day: Although the oral dose here is adequate, the topical ointment needs to be applied more frequently to manage the active viral infection effectively.

Viral Keratitis (HSV Keratitis):

  • Etiology: HSV is the most common cause of viral keratitis. It can manifest as primary infection or reactivation of latent virus.
  • Clinical Features: Pain, redness, photophobia, blurred vision, tearing, and dendritic corneal ulcers. Fluorescein staining highlights these ulcers, showing branching with terminal bulbs.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis is confirmed with slit-lamp examination and fluorescein staining. PCR can also be used for viral detection.
  • Treatment:
    • Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day for 7-10 days (or equivalent antivirals like valacyclovir or famciclovir).
    • Acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day for 7-10 days.
    • Topical corticosteroids are contraindicated in epithelial disease but may be used cautiously in stromal disease under antiviral coverage.
  • Complications: Delayed or inadequate treatment can result in corneal scarring, stromal keratitis, or even blindness.
  • Prevention: Long-term suppressive antiviral therapy may be recommended for patients with recurrent HSV keratitis to reduce the frequency of episodes.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of a gray patch of the lumbo-sacral region in neonate?
questions.solution:
• Dermal melanocytosis (mongolian spot) is a benign melanocytic lesion that occurs in more than 90% of African-American infants, more than 80% of Asian infants, 70% of Hispanic infants, and close to 10% of Caucasian infants.
  • The lesions appear as gray, blue-black, or brown patches, most commonly over the lumbosacral back and buttocks.
  • Most are present at birth and fade in the first 2 to 3 years of life, although occasionally they persist into adulthood.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a rural area presents with dry eyes, night blindness, and foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva.His diet is predominantly based on rice and lacks fruits or vegetables. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The child presents with Bitot's spots, which are triangular, foamy, or foamy white lesions on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually seen in the temporal region. They are a sign of Vitamin A deficiency, often associated with a diet lacking in fruits, vegetables, and animal products. This condition is common in developing countries, especially in children with malnutrition.

  • The treatment for Vitamin A deficiency includes oral Vitamin A supplementation to replenish the body’s stores and prevent further ocular and systemic complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the following regimen:
    • For children aged 1-6 years: 200,000 IU of Vitamin A orally on two consecutive days, with a third dose 4-6 weeks later.
    • For infants under 1 year: 100,000 IU of Vitamin A orally on two consecutive days.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Topical antibiotics: These are used for treating bacterial conjunctivitis or keratitis, not for treating Bitot’s spots or Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Option B. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF: This is used in the treatment of neovascular conditions like diabetic retinopathy or wet age-related macular degeneration, not for Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Option D. Topical corticosteroids: These may be used for inflammatory conditions of the eye, but they have no role in treating Vitamin A deficiency or Bitot’s spots.

Bitot’s Spots and Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Etiology: Bitot’s spots are a sign of Vitamin A deficiency, which occurs due to inadequate dietary intake of Vitamin A-rich foods like green leafy vegetables, carrots, liver, and dairy products. It is particularly common in children and pregnant women in developing countries.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bitot’s spots: Foamy, whitish, triangular patches on the temporal conjunctiva, typically in both eyes.
    • Other symptoms of Vitamin A deficiency include xerophthalmia (dry eyes), night blindness, and in severe cases, corneal ulcers and keratomalacia.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation and dietary history. Blood tests may reveal low serum retinol levels.
  • Treatment:
    • Oral Vitamin A supplementation is the mainstay of treatment.
    • The WHO guidelines for Vitamin A supplementation are tailored based on the child's age and the severity of deficiency. Vitamin A supplementation is crucial in preventing blindness and other systemic complications, such as increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Prevention: Ensuring adequate dietary intake of Vitamin A through fortified foods or regular supplementation in high-risk populations can prevent the development of Bitot’s spots and other deficiency-related complications.

questions.text: Identify the probable condition from the given skull X ray?
questions.solution:
• The skull x ray is suggestive of Hair on end appearance.
  • 'Hair-on-end' sign is seen in the diploic spaces on the skull radiographs appearing like long, thin vertical striations that resemble hairs standing on ends.
  • Hair-on-end appearance of the skull is a characteristic feature of chronic hemolysis usually seen in patients with thalassemia and sickle cell anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old contact lens wearer presents with severe eye pain, redness, and blurred vision for the past week. She reports improper contact lens hygiene, often using tap water to clean her lenses. On slit-lamp examination,shown findings are noted. Her symptoms appear disproportionate to the clinical findings. For the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is Acanthamoeba keratitis is a severe, often painful corneal infection caused by the protozoan Acanthamoeba, commonly associated with improper contact lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.
  • The organism can penetrate the corneal epithelium, causing characteristic ring-shaped stromal infiltrates, which may appear later in the disease. The pain is often disproportionate to the clinical findings.
  • Confocal microscopy is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help visualize Acanthamoeba cysts in the corneal stroma, making it one of the first-line investigations for suspected Acanthamoeba keratitis. This method can quickly identify the presence of the pathogen without invasive procedures.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B. Corneal biopsy: While this is an option for confirming diagnosis in severe or resistant cases, it is more invasive and generally not the first investigation.
  • Option C. Gram stain of corneal scrapings: Acanthamoeba cysts are not visible with a Gram stain, which is more suited for bacterial infections.
  • Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for herpes simplex virus: This would be useful in cases of viral keratitis but not for detecting Acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

  • Etiology: Caused by the free-living protozoan Acanthamoeba. Risk factors include poor contact lens hygiene, exposure to contaminated water (e.g., tap water, swimming pools).
  • Clinical Features: Severe eye pain, redness, photophobia, tearing, blurred vision, and a ring-shaped corneal infiltrate (in later stages). Pain is often out of proportion to the visible clinical findings.
  • Diagnosis: Confocal microscopy, corneal scraping with culture on non-nutrient agar, PCR for Acanthamoeba.
  • Treatment: Early treatment involves antiamoebic agents such as polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or chlorhexidine. In advanced cases, a corneal transplant may be required.
  • Prognosis: Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for preserving vision. Delayed diagnosis can lead to severe corneal damage and even loss of vision.

questions.text: The given image shows jugular foramen in the base of the skull. All of the following structures passes through it except?
questions.solution:
The jugular foramen contains the following structures:

Cranial nerves IX, X, and XI

These nerves originate from the brainstem and exit the cranium through the jugular foramen.

Internal jugular vein

Passes through the jugular foramen.

Jugular fossa

A compartment within the jugular foramen that contains the glossopharyngeal nerve, the Jacobson nerve, and the inferior petrosal sinus.

Inferior petrosal sinus

Drains the cavernous sinus and exits through the pars nervosa of the jugular foramen.

Jugular bulb

Located in the larger posterolateral pars vascularis of the jugular foramen.

Cochlear aqueduct

Houses the perilymphatic duct and a tubular prolongation of the dura mater that is filled with CSF.

The jugular foramen is a large opening in the base of the skull, located between the occipital bone and the petrous part of the temporal bone. It’s formed by the temporal bone and the occipital bone.

questions.text: A term boy is born limp and gets intubated in labor room. Baby is ventilated and put on SIMV mode of ventilation. His x ray is as follows. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

choices.text: Prior otitis media is not an exclusion criteria

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with congenital cholesteatoma. His otoendoscopy examination is shown in the image given below. Which of the following feature is not a part of Levenson s criteria for congenital cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The Levenson criteria for diagnosing congenital cholesteatoma (CC) are:

  1. A pearly white mass is medial to an intact tympanic membrane
  2. The pars tensa and pars flaccida are normal
  3. There is no history of otorrhea, perforation, or previous otologic procedure.

Canal atresia, intramembranous cholesteatoma, and giant cholesteatoma are excluded

Levenson revised the criteria to include previous bouts of otitis media or effusion, which were not previously considered exclusion criteria.

Early diagnosis of CC is important to avoid extensive damage to the middle ear, achieve better hearing outcomes, and reduce the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient has axillary freckling, several firm subcutaneous masses on both arms and seven light-brown macules on his trunk which are greater than 1.5 cm as shown in the image. What will be the probable diagnosis of the child?
questions.solution:
• Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal dominant disorder, producing tumors along the course of nerves and occasionally resulting in marked soft tissue or bony deformity.
  • In > 90%, characteristic skin lesions are apparent at birth or develop during infancy.
  • Lesions are medium-brown (café-au-lait), freckle-like macules, distributed most commonly over the trunk, pelvis, and flexor creases of elbows and knees.
  • During late childhood, flesh-colored cutaneous tumors of various sizes and shapes appear, ranging in number from several to thousands.
  • Diagnosis is clinical. There is no specific treatment, but tumors can be removed surgically.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with complain of severe ear ache. His otoendoscopy examination reveals the following image. Which of the following organism is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common organisms that cause acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) are: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

These organisms are also the most common bacteria that cause sinusitis and pneumonia.

ASOM is a pyogenic infection of the middle ear cleft that lasts less than three weeks. It usually causes: severe deep ear pain, fever, and conductive hearing loss in the affected ear.

ASOM progresses through stages, including: Hyperemia, Exudation, and Suppuration.

ASOM is more common in children because they are more susceptible to upper respiratory tract infections and have shorter, wider, and more horizontal eustachian tubes.

questions.text: A 12-day newborn baby is brought to you by parents with painful perianal rashes as follows. What should be the line of management for the baby?
questions.solution:
• The child has painful vesicular rashes as shown, which is likely to be herpes infection.
  • Infants with skin, eye, and mouth disease generally present at 5-11 days of life and typically demonstrate these small vesicles,
  • In contrast to children and adults, neonates with suspected herpes skin lesions require parenteral antiviral therapy to prevent more serious sequelae as well as CSF analysis to define the extent of disease. HSV PCR of the CSF is the standard for diagnosis.
  • Tzanck smears have low sensitivity and EEG ma have nonspecific findings (option b, c). The absence of fever does not indicate that the rash is from a benign etiology.

questions.text: A 36 year old patient presented with scaling and crust with erosions predominantly over face, scalp, upper chest and upperback. Nikolsky's sign was positive. Mucosa were normal. On histopathology, there was subcorneal split. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In Pemphigus vulgaris

  • oral mucous membranes are usually affected with or without skin involvement,
  • Flaccid blisters-which may occur anywhere on the skin surface-are the primary lesion of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Histologically there is suprabasal cleft with acantholytic cells. 

Pemphigus foliaceous

  • only the skin is affected.
  • the blister is even more fragile than in PV, and therefore skin lesions usually present as scaly-crusted small erosions,
  • Histologically, there is subcorneal cleft.

The Nikolsky sign is positive in PF patients with active disease.

Bullous pemphigoid

  • mainly affects elderly people
  • starts with pruritus and urticated and erythematous lesions.
  • Later, tense blisters are characteristic both on erythematous and on normal skin.
  • Mucosal :in a minority of patients and is not predominant.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal splitting.

Key takeaway:

Pemphigus foliaceous

  • only the skin is affected.
  • the blister is even more fragile than in PV, and therefore skin lesions usually present as scaly-crusted small erosions,
  • Histologically, there is subcorneal cleft.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with a genital ulcer for 1 week. Examination revealed a painless, single, well-defined indurated ulcer and painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. He has a history of unprotected intercourse one month ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Primary syphilis is characterized by a solitary, painless genital ulcer (chancre) and painless lymphadenopathy.
  • The indurated nature of the ulcer and the timeline following unprotected intercourse support this diagnosis, with an incubation period of 9-90 days.

Option A) Herpes progenitalis


  • Typically presents with multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain. It can lead to recurrent lesions.

Option B) Chancroid

  • Characterized by painful ulcers and associated painful lymphadenopathy, which does not fit this case.

Option D) Lymphogranuloma venereum

  • Initially presents with a painless ulcer but is followed by painful lymphadenopathy, and this patient has no indication of the later stages.

Key takeaway

  • Solitary, painless indurated genital ulcer
  • Painless lymphadenopathi
  • IP: 9-90 days

Tag:

  • Primary Syphilis

choices.text: Saddle joint - Carpometacarpal joint of the thumb

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match between the type of joint and its example?
questions.solution:
Atlanto-Occipital Joint

  • The atlanto-occipital joint is a condyloid (ellipsoid) joint, enabling nodding and limited side-to-side motion.
  • Key anatomical features:
    • The atlas (C1) lacks a vertebral body and spinous process.
    • It has two concave superior facets that articulate with the occipital condyles.
    • Approximately 50% of total neck flexion and extension occurs at the occiput-C1 articulation.

Atlanto-Axial Joint

  • The atlanto-axial joint is a pivot (diarthrodial) joint, allowing rotational movement (e.g., shaking the head "no").
  • Key anatomical features:
    • The base of the dens narrows due to the transverse ligament.
    • Approximately 50% of total neck rotation occurs at the C1-C2 articulation.
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Pannus formation in rheumatoid arthritis can affect this articulation, leading to instability.

Other Types of Joints

  • Ball-and-socket joint (e.g., shoulder, hip): Allows multi-axial movement.
  • Hinge joint (e.g., elbow, knee): Allows movement in one plane.
  • Saddle joint (e.g., thumb): Allows biaxial movement.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Medial epicondyle-

  • The medial epicondyle is a prominent bony projection on the medial aspect of lower end of humerus.
  • It is sub-cutaneous and can be easily felt on the lower end of humerus.
  • It serves as a common origin point of superficial flexor muscles of forearm called as the 'common flexor origin'.

Radial head -

  • It is disc shaped and covered with hyaline cartilage.
  • It is concave superiorly and articulates with capitulum of humerus.
  • The circumference of the head is also articular and sit in the radial notch of ulna to form the superior radio-ulnar joint.

Capitulum -

  • It is a rounder projection in the lower end of humerus which articulates with the radial head.

Lateral epicondyle -

  • It is smaller than medial epicondyle. It serves as origin point for extensor muscles of forearm called the 'common extensor origin'.

questions.text: Which neurological condition is depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
Option A: Generalized tonic clonic seizure


  • It is characterized by widespread, high-amplitude spikes and slow waves.
  • These abnormal brain activities are typically seen as generalized discharges, often involving both hemispheres, corresponding with the tonic and clonic phases of the seizure.

Option B: Absent seizure


  • It shows generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges

Option C: Lenox Gastaut syndrome


  • Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS) is a severe form of epilepsy characterized by multiple seizure types, cognitive impairment, and developmental delays.
  • EEG findings often show slow, high-amplitude theta or delta activity, with interictal generalized spike-and-wave or multifocal epileptiform discharges, especially during seizures.

Option D: Myoclonus

Topic : EEG, Abesnce seizure

  • Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive therapy that uses magnetic pulses to stimulate specific brain areas.

questions.text: What is shown in the given picture?
questions.solution:
• Bispectral analysis is the statistical study of phenomena made at two wavelengths of nonlinear character. The BIS index derives data from a complex EEG parameter combining several variables from the frequency domain (power spectrum, bispectrum, beta ratio, SyncFastSlow) and time domain (burst suppression) analyzed in real time.
  • The BIS index is a continuous processed multifactorial EEG parameter denoted by a dimensionless number with a range from 0 to 100.
  • Non Anesthetized awake patients have a BIS reading between 90 and 100 and total brain cortical activity suppression (isoelectric) results in a 0 reading. Readings over 70 are suggestive of patients most likely to be conscious and probably able to follow verbal commands and the ability to recall events during the procedure.
  • The optimal suggested BIS value for general anesthesia with low probability of explicit recall and unresponsive to verbal stimulus is between 40 and 60.
  • A BIS value below 40 corresponds to deep sedation with increasing burst suppression on the EEG signal till cortical silence (isoelectricEEG) BIS 0.

questions.text: Identify the grading of laryngoscopy:
questions.solution:
Widely accepted classification (of Cormack and Lehane) according to the best view possible at direct laryngoscopy:


  • grade 1: complete glottis visible.
  • grade 2: anterior glottis not seen.
  • grade 3: epiglottis seen but not glottis.
  • grade 4: epiglottis not seen.

Grades 3 and 4 together are often termed 'difficult'.

questions.text: 72-year-old male patient present in neurology OPD with complaint of recurrent backward falls and progressive weakness with imbalance, accompanying relative complain of sluggish movement while doing routine work, MRI brain of patient was done and image is given below: Which of the following sign is depicted in given MRI images?
questions.solution:
Hummingbird sign - Case of progressive supranuclear palsy.

MRI findings in progressive supranuclear palsy - Parkinson plus syndrome:

Midbrain atrophy:

  1. Increased MRI parkinsonism index.
  2. Reduced midbrain to pons ratio
  3. Hummingbird sign - flattening of the superior aspect of the midbrain which usually shows a normal convex profile.
  4. Mickey mouse sign - reduction in antero-posterior and midline diameter of midbrain in axial images.
  5. Morning glory sign - loss of normal lateral convex margin of the tegmentum of midbrain.

Ice cream cone sign - seen in acoustic neuroma / vestibular schwannoma.

Empty delta sign - seen in cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.
